title: andrews law path to peace family pc
story: We were moved partly because he died in the line of duty after responding to a call about a burglary. But also because he was only  years old and had been married to his beautul we Lissie for just a month.It was heartbreaking to see the photos of the pair overflowing with love and happiness at their wedding — while knowing his le had been needlessly ended.Our hearts went out to Lissie, who no doubt is still trying to make sense of the tragedy. So too his mother and father. For any parent, such a loss is unthinkable. Nobody should have to bury their child.It is against the natural order of things, especially when your beloved son or daughter has been murdered.That kind of pain will never go away. It becomes the defining moment of a parent’s le.Who would blame someone in that position for opting out of le ­altogether and sinking into inertia and depression  To me, that even seems the most likely response.Instead, his mum Debbie Adlam has hit the campaign trail, arguing for longer sentences for anyone who kills a policeman.PC Harper’s killers were convicted of manslaughter but cleared of ­murder.Henry Long, , who drove the getaway car, was jailed for  years. His accomplices Albert ­Bowers and Jessie Cole, both , were each given  years.Unduly lenient sentences, to my mind — and probably yours too.On Wednesday, Lissie began a campaign to bring in “Andrew’s Law”, in memory of her late husband. She wants anyone who kills a police officer, firefighter, nurse, doctor or paramedic to be jailed for le — meaning a minimum of  years.Mrs Adlam, who has been robbed of growing old happily with her beloved son in her le, has joined the campaign.“We got to the end of our trial and we didn’t feel like justice had been done,” she said. “We felt like we had been punched.“We didn’t walk away feeling that we had done Andrew proud.”That is the nub of the matter. She wants to do right by her late son. And I imagine she will not rest until she feels she has done that.It is only when tragedy strikes that many people realise how strong and determined they can be.Nothing can bring back PC Harper. ButAndrew’s Law comes to pass, acting as a deterrent to other criminals, at least one positive will have come from an otherwise senseless death.The need for justice is a stronger force than most of us can comprehend. I think of Stephen Lawrence’s mother Doreen, whose le changed overnight when her son was ­murdered in a racist attack in .She campaigned tirelessly for reforms to the police service and founded the Stephen Lawrence Charitable Trust.She forged positive change from the tragic murder of her son, ­showing the strength of her feeling and the scale of her loss.I think also of Michael and Sara Payne who also campaigned with great determination after the murder of their eight-year-old daughter Sarah.As a result, parents and ­carers can now formally ask the police for information about a person who has contact with a childthey fear that person poses a threat.Then there is the Jodie Chesney Foundation, set up by Peter Chesney to tackle kne crime after his daughter was murdered last year.When faced with unimaginable loss, some people respond by taking action to change things.They are gripped with the strength to move mountains — and get the law changed.We salute their courage and their determination to find light amid the terrible darkness of their loss.How sad it is seeing footage of Keeley Bunker dancing with her trusted friend Wesley Streete, who walked her home that evening . . . then went on to murder her.Keeley was a beautul young woman, just  when she died and with her whole le ahead of her.But her “friend” chose to end that le.It is tragic seeing any le wasted – and for what  Streete’s own gratication.Let us hope he is haunted by his actions and choices for the rest of his le.Wonderful news this week as the parents of poor Charlie Gard – who died of a rare genetic condition three years ago – gave birth to a healthy baby boy.As Connie Yates said: “The world feels a whole lot more beautul this morning”.I am so happy for them after the tragedy of losing Charlie, and what a beautul baby.Congratulations.WARNINGS this week that menopausal women could be unfairly denied entry to pubs and restaurantstheir hot flushes are confused in temperature checks for Covid symptoms.Take note: No one in their right mind should keep a menopausal woman from her chilled white wine . . .It feels a bit like a sword of Damocles is hanging over the nation at the moment, with yet more job cuts announced this week – at LGH Hotels, Pizza Express and Wetherspoons.Thousands more workers are living in fear of redundancy. It is a scary prospect. But don’t panic.The best defence is preparation. Find ways to be positive. That means not taking it personally.The ROLE is redundant, not you. So don’t view redundancy as a reflection of your ability or your worth.Know your rights and get the best settlement you can. A proper redundancy process comes with a consultation period, which will give you time to weigh up your options.My advice is to engage in that process. Ask for written clarication of any offer andyou are unhappy in any way, there are plenty of employment lawyers you can talk to. Or free help is available from Acas.Sort out your finances. Work out how much money you need for day-to-day living and,you can, keep some back for emergencies. Cut out spending on non-essentials and work out how to manage everything from mortgage payments to credit card debt.You might have to tighten your belt for a bit but that’s not the end of the word. For many people, redundancy is a chance to consider what they might do dferently.That is easier said than done but try to see it as an opportunity – to go freelance, start a business, become a consultant, get another job or re-enter education – rather than an ending.I love a romantic gesture as much as anyone.But the -year-old man who spelled out “Marry Me” using  tea lights made me wonderhe might have found another way.The candles set fire to the living room and seriously damaged the flat he shared with his girlfriend.But she still said yes!And at least she knows what she is getting herself into.It is always hard seeing photos of people enjoying a holiday in the sun when you are working.And this year, more than ever, I’ve been consumed with envy of the lucky souls who somehow got away despite all the travel restrictions.Having seen multiple beachtastic photos of Coleen and Wayne Rooney, who jetted off to the Caribbean what seems like weeks ago, is it wrong of me to admit I’ll be quite pleased when the holiday season is over We need a word for the irritated envy of others’ amazing holidays.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government must get kids back in class this september
story: The militant teaching unions are far more concerned with bringing down this Tory government than they will ever be about educating your children.Mary Bousted, the tight-lipped commissar of the National Education Union, snarls that it is “impossible” for schools to re-open fully next month and that making it compulsory for all children to attend is “a real risk” by the evil Tories.Mary increasingly sounds like an Arthur Scargill tribute band.Are we really going to let this kamikaze Corbynista play politics with millions of children It is not just the comrades who boss the nation’s teaching unions parking their tanks outside school gates. Labour councillors and MPs shake their heads about the dangers of opening while never reflecting on the risk of keeping schools closed.Even Labour’s new leader Sir Keir Starmer is worried about safety . . .  and his own children attended school during lockdown.The risks to children from Covid- are next to non-existent. Teachers are more likely to be hit by a bus than contract coronavirus from kids.Butthe risks of the schools opening in September are minimal, the cost of schools staying shut is beyond measure.Already, a generation of kids have seen their education become another victim of coronavirus.Some , of them could not sit their GCSEs in spring. And , could not sit their A levels.The years below them, due to sit those le-changing exams next spring, have lost six months of their education they will never recover.A report by the National Foundation for Educational Research said  per cent of state-school children had between none and one online lesson a day during the long months of lockdown.The most disadvantaged children have suffered the most.The schools are due to open in just  days and the vast majority of parents — almost  per cent — want them to start as planned.But even as Gavin Williamson was making his bold promise to throw open the school gates, Business ­Secretary Alok Sharma was mewing that school closures would be ­considered on a “case by case” basis, while Schools minister Nick Gibb bleats he can’t “decree” that every pupil will be back at their desk in September. These timid Tories must start showing some spine.With the schools closed, parents cannotto work. Already unemployment is soaring. Already there are hard times ahead.If parents and their children stay at home during the autumn months, this country will be on its knees for years.The A-level results will be announced this Thursday and the class of  will finally discover the damage that Covid- has done to their dreams.For the first time ever, A-level grades will be estimated, and there are countless families across the country holding their breath, me included.But for the millions of children meant to be in school, the future is even more uncertain.If their schools do not open in September it will be a craven act of surrender to extremist teaching unions.And a national tragedy that ­effectively chucks an entire generation on the scrapheap.IT is  years since Cameron Diaz made her movie debut opposite Jim Carrey in The Mask and six years since her last film.Cameron says retiring from the movies has brought her the peace she has always craved.And, of course, having an estimated £million in the bank usually has a calming effect.The thieving simpletons responsible for his death will all be free before they turn .The police get endless stick these days. But PC Andrew Harper was the best of us.Andrew had been married to his childhood sweetheart Lissie for just four weeks when he was dragged to his death after becoming entangled in a tow rope dangling from the back of a car being used to steal a quad bike.Driver Henry Long, , got  years. Albert Bowers and Jessie Cole, both , got  years. Not once have they shown even a flicker of remorse. But the law allows a third of a term off sentences for murder and manslaughter.Now Andrew’s widow Lissie has launched a campaign for “Andrew’s Law”, which will mean a full le term for killing  workers.“I wish to ensure any widows of the future will not have to experience the same miscarriage of justice,” says Lissie, . “I pledge to my late husband to never stop until I have made the dference this country needs.”I know that every reader of this paper will wish Lissie well.The sentences handed down to Long, Bowers and Cole might be what we would expect for manslaughter convictions.But God knows it does not feel very much like justice.“NO one here gets out alive,” sang The Doors’ Jim Morrison.Jim could have been thinking of Public Health England, the quango of clowns charged with protecting the nation’s health and wellbeing.PHE has developed a unique way of counting our corona- virus dead. If you catch Covid-, PHE claims you as a virus victim evenyou recover and die many months later of something .Who does their maths, Diane Abbott PHE’s madcap counting system means all , cases of coronavirus in England will eventually be added to the UK’s Covid- death toll – because we all have to go some time.PHE receives £million of your money a year to produce this garbage.The explosion has left more than  dead, , hurt and , homeless.Israa Seblani, , is the bride who was posing for wedding photos at the very moment the Lebanese capital was devastated by the huge blast.A doctor herself, Israa helped the wounded before seeking safety. A reminder that, even in the midst of tragedy, there is still kindness, decency and courage.CALAIS politician Pierre-Henri Dumont says: “Maybe we should do more” to stop migrants crossing the Channel. Love that “maybe”, monsieur!Priti Patel threatens to send in the Royal Navy but that shouldn’t be necessary. It is contrary to international law that these desperate souls are not claiming asylum in the first safe country they reach.But as they continue to arrive here on a daily basis, you have to say they look happy to have reached this country from the war-torn wastelands of, er, France.Perhaps the UK is not quite the racist hellhole it is frequently cracked up to be.THE Government is mocked for launching its wildly popular Eat Out To Help Out scheme while, at the same time, Boris is posing in gyms and waging his private war on obesity. But they are both great ideas. There is a place in everyone’s le for regular exercise and regular peri-peri chicken.So it is odd that every picture of Summer Monteys-Fullam – hanging out with her horse, posing with her glamorous mum, running with her dog Cookie – is accompanied by the demeaning appendage “Bake Off judge Paul Hollywood’s ex-girlfriend.” To some of us, Summer means more than Paul.Or as we like to think of him: “Paul Hollywood, , the ex-boyfriend of Summer Monteys-Fullam.”AFTER repeatedly punching his greyhound in the face, Joseph Pocklington, , has been banned from keeping pets for two years.If a dog was guilty of such a brutal assault, it would be put down. Pathetic – both the sentence and the man.VIEWERS of Monday night’s episode of Coronation Street were gobsmacked to see a sign for the street’s chip shop, For Your Fries Only, with what looked like . . . well, that’s certainly not a large portion of cod, is it What made it even worse was the thing, right, was flashing.KATIE PRICE has her feet in plaster after cracking her heels jumping off a wall at a theme park. It could happen to anyone.But you know you’re getting old when Katie Price has got her legs wrapped around a young man because he is helping her into her wheelchair.PAUL MESCAL, who never got out of the studenty sports-casual look in BBC’s Normal People, wears an unkempt black tie in the video for Scarlet, the new Rolling Stones track.I am amazed that Paul, , has not yet been seriously touted as the next James Bond.This strong, sensitive Irish hunk wears black tie as well as Sean Connery.And he would be an infinitely better  than any of the ageing thespians who are usually predicted to replace Daniel Craig.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick said it will wreck the chances of pubs and cafes bouncing back from the lockdown.He has intervened after Manchester City Council announced it will make all outdoor areas smoke-free to avoid a new health crisis.The city’s neighbourhoods chief Rabnawaz Akbar said that, after months inside, people don’t want “a face full of smoke” while trying to enjoy a meal or drink.But Mr Jenrick fired off a letter warning him a ban would be against the spirit of emergency laws to support businesses in the pandemic.He wrote: “If smoking were banned outside pubs and cafes, as you suggest it will be in Manchester, it could lead to signicant closures across the country.”There is far less harm from secondary smoke outside, than inside.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mauritius oil tanker leak emergency declared
story: Shocking satellite images show a dark slick oozing through the turquoise waters near environmentally sensitive areas after The MV Wakashio struck a coral reef off the island nation on July .As the deadly slick closed in, anxious locals stuffed sacks with leaves and created makesht straw barriers to protect the famous honeymoon resort.Photos of volunteers show them covered in the thick black sludge.Prime Minister Pravind Jugnauth said the spill “represents a danger” for the country of some . million people that relies heavily on tourism and has been been hit hard by the effects of the coronavirus pandemic.Marine protected areas in Mauritius cover an extent of  sq miles , including six fishing reserves and two marine parks.Jugnauth told journalists that the boats documents and black boxes have been recovered, reports Le Xpress from Mauritius.France revealed it is now sending specialist help from its nearby Reunion Island. Equipment is also being sent from Greece to help the clean-up operation.The Mauritius government is taking all necessary actions so as to contain the oil spill from the MV Wakashio and some  sea booms have been deployed to secure the sensitive areas, said Environment Minister Kavydass Ramano.The vessel has grounded in a very sensitive zone which includes the Blue Bay Marine Park, Iles aux Aigrettes, and the Ramsar sites.The operator of the Japanese bulk carrier apologised on Sunday.Japan is sending a six-person disaster relief team, on the request of the Mauritius government, to help with removing the spilt oil, according to a statement by the Japanese Foreign Ministry on Sunday.“We apologise profusely and deeply for the great trouble we have caused,” Akihiko Ono, executive vice president of Mitsui OSK Lines said at a news conference in Tokyo.He added that the company would “do everything in their power to resolve the issue”.Mauritius says the ship was carrying nearly , tonnes of fuel when it became stuck.Wildle volunteers ferried dozens of baby tortoises and rare plants from an island near the area of spill - Ile aux Aigrettes - to the mainland.Locals and environmentalists are now asking why the authorities didnt act more quickly after the ship ran aground more than two weeks ago.Fears are now growing that the worsening weather could tear the Japanese-owned ship apart along its cracked hull.France said a military transport aircraft was carrying pollution control equipment to Mauritius and a navy vessel with additional material is to set sail for the island.When bioersity is in peril, there is urgency to act, French President Emmanuel Macron tweeted on Saturday.Some  tonnes of oil have been salvaged from the ship, but there are still , tonnes remaining on board.The tanker was carrying both diesel and bunker fuel - which is used by maritime vessels.Cracks in the hull were detected a few days ago and the salvage team was quickly evacuated. Le Xpress reports that the smell of fuel oil is so overwhelming that it has terried Intendant Laval Bangard, , who was born on the island.The fisherman told the publication that he had never seen an ecological disaster of this magnitude.Some  sea booms were deployed to contain the spill, but they were not enough.Our country doesnt have the skills and expertise to refloat stranded ships, the PM said on Friday. Environment Minister Kavydass Ramano said a salvage team of  members were working to secure and stabilise the ship - but had to be evacuated due to the cracks in the ship hull.A technical team is assessing the situation and has a technical plan to start pumping out the fuel at the earliest opportunity, he added. Bad weather has made it impossible to act, and I worry what could happen Sunday when the weather deteriorates, he said.Heavy winds are expected to push the oil slick even farther along the mainlands shore.Thousands of students, environmental activists and residents of Mauritius were working around the clock on Sunday, trying to reduce the damage.“This is no longer a threat to our environment, it is a full-blown ecological disaster that has affected one of the most environmentally important parts of Mauritius, the Mahebourg Lagoon,” said Sunil Dowarkasing, an environmental consultant and former MP.“The people of Mauritius, thousands and thousands, have come out to try to prevent as much damage as possible,” added Dowarkasing.He said people have created long floating oil booms to try to slow the spread into the lagoon and onto the coast. The hastily made fabric booms are stuffed with sugar cane leaves and straw and kept afloat with plastic bottles, he said. People are also using empty oil drums to scoop up as much oil as possible from shallower waters.“We are working flat out. It’s a major challenge, because the oil is not only floating in the lagoon, it’s already washing up on the shore.“The booms are really working in many spots,” said Dowarkasing.Greenpeace Africa warned that hundreds of tonnes of diesel and oil has leaked into the water. Thousands of species around the pristine lagoons of Blue Bay, Pointe dEsny and Mahebourg are at risk of drowning in a sea of pollution, said Greenpeaces climate and energy manager, Happy Khambule.The country also has appealed to the United Nations for urgent aid, including experts in containing oil spills and environmental protection.A police inquiry has been opened into possible negligence, the government said.Neither Mitsui OSK Lines nor Nagashiki Shipping, the ships owner, could confirm the cost of damages from the oil spill. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teens plotted school massacre columbine
story: John L Schultz IV, , and Donald V. Robin Jr, , have both been arrested as they allegedly planned to shoot up two schools in Rochester, Indiana. Cops received a tip-off from an informant on July  that Schultz said he and some of his friends were waiting for schools to open to commit a massacre, reports ABC.The teen is alleged to have bragged they were plotting to kill as many as they can and kill themselves just like Columbine.Eric Harris, , and Dylan Klebold,  murdered  students and one teacher when they stormed their school in Columbine, Colorado, in April, .Robin and Schultz are alleged to have bought themselves black trench coats similar to those worn by Harris and Klebold, reports WSBT.Both also had tattoos of guns with quotes from Klebold and Harris and listened to music about the massacre.They had discussed a suicide pact on Facebook and talked about killing a bunch of human scum. Court documents claim they also gave themselves the same nicknames used by Harris and Klebold - and sent each other pictures of the two killers.It is alleged they planned to carry out the bloodbath when schools ed next month as most classes have been closed since March.Detectives reportedly viewed Schultz and Robins Facebook profiles and obtained search warrants to view their private conversations.Police are said to have discovered multiple messages planning out massacres at Rochester High School and Caston High School in Rochester, Indiana. Robin allegedly said he wanted everyone there dead, according to a probable cause affidavit. He allegedly wrote he would kill a security guard before roaming the halls killing people before heading into classrooms.Robin allegedly even estimated how long it would take a SWAT team to arrive at each Rochester and Caston schools. Police claim Robin revealed he had an itch to shoot up a school, claiming he had once sat outside Rochester Middle School for  minutes with an AR when he was in eighth grade.He wrote that he planned to kill  or more people, with  magazines packed in a duffel bag, and then himself before reportedly deciding it was too risky.Meanwhile, it is alleged Schultz wrote to one unnamed friend that “we are gonna do it i wanna shoot up a school with him”.He added: “I want him to stay out of trouble till we can shoot up the place.Police allegedly found a June  conversation revealed more details about the plan - including a potential suicide pact.Robin is reported to have said im killing myself after I kill a bunch of people and but im killing myself after I kill a bunch of people.Allegedly, Schultz said: I does exist donny just like no matter what im doin the same for u bc u guys are my family we had bad childhoods and we will always stick together u guys fr mean everything to me.In another conversation on Facebook, Robin is alleged to have said he had a gun locked in my dads safe and later discussed shooting up an airport, festivals or Black churches.Police also alleged Schultz had multiple conversations on Facebook about either trying to buy illegal narcotics or others asking for his help selling illegal narcotics.Robin also alleged had a friend buy him a hat for the band KMFDM , whose lyrics were posted by Harris before the Columbine massacre. The friend said: Cant believe Im buying you a school shooter hat butit makes you happy.Robin is said to have replied its not a school shooter hat, its a band hat.Fulton County Prosecutor Michael Marrs said: So I mean, anytime anyone’s obsessed with Columbine, yes, it’s a fine line between free speech and when you cross the line, but I think in this case, clearly what they had done was going to interfere with the occupancy of a school.He added: Anything like this, were going to take extremely seriously because I think history has shown us that sadly, these kind of things do get carried out. And were not going to take it lightly.Marrs added more information about the case would be released in the coming weeks.Charges of  conspiracy to commit murder and intimidation were filed against the pair on July .Schultz is being held at the Fulton County Jail and Robin, still a minor, is being held in a juvenile detention center but will be transferred when he turns  later this month.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: girl born stomach liver bowel
story: Laurel Phizacklea, two, was not expected survive birth and her parents were offered a termination at their -week scan.Parents Kelly, , and Sean, , were told their unborn child had a major exomphalos - a condition which occurs when the babys abdominal wall does not form during pregnancy.They decided to go ahead with the pregnancy and their little Laurel was born in Addenbrookes Hospital, Cambridge on June , .The toddler has defied all odds and still lives with stomach, liver and bowel outside her body.Most babies with her condition have the organs reinserted in their body at birth, but because her exomphalos is unusually large doctors said they cant internalise them until she is three.Laurel was left with a protruding bump on her tiny tummy.Her parents keep it wrapped in bandages to support the external organs and to prevent the weight of them pulling anything  out of her body. Skin has since formed around the organs.Laurel can eat, drink and go to the toilet like any other toddler, but her parents need to make sure no injuries come to her exomphalos.The little tot has even grown to love her tummy.Mum Kelly, a volunteer supporting parents in neonatal care, said: She loves her tummy so much.She rubs it in the bath when I take the dressing off to wash her and says ah tummy.Its very cute, and she couldnt be prouder of it. But I do worry about how shell react when its not there anymore.Early in all pregnancies, the intestine develops inside the umbilical cord and then usually moves inside the abdomen a few weeks later.In exomphalos, the intestines - and in this case the stomach, liver and bowel - remain inside the umbilical cord but outside the abdomen.Kelly said: I dont know how we remained positive throughout my pregnancy with Laurel.It really looked asshe wouldnt survive birth - but Sean and I never gave up hope and she has done us so proud.Her pouch of organs on her tummy is a part of her and she doesnt let it get her down.Laurel is a true inspiration and amazes us every day.Doctors also determined the baby had a spinal deformity - and the pair were offered a termination.Kelly said she was shocked they were offered an abortion at her -week scan.She said: We couldnt quite believe what we were hearing when they offered us an abortion.People kept saying: Its OK, you can try again - but I didnt want another baby.I was so in love with this baby and we knew we would do everything we could for her. Exomphalos is when when the babys abdominal wall does not form during pregnancy.Early in all pregnancies, the intestine develops inside the umbilical cord and then usually moves inside the abdomen a few weeks later.In exomphalos, the intestines remain inside the umbilical cord but outside the abdomen.The abdominal cavity often does not develop properly and remains small in size.The continued on with the pregnancy and went for scans every two weeks - and because the presence of exomphalos signal an  per cent chance of other birth abnormalities the mum underwent further tests.Those tests highlighted their unborn child also had a hole in the heart.Three weeks before Laurel’s birth, doctors also discovered the exomphalos had doubled in size – prompting doctors to give the devastating news that the baby would not survive childbirth.Kelly said: Although I knew it was very real and incredibly scary, part of me always thought: This wont happen to me, I wont let it.Surgeons performed a classic caesarean - meaning they cut vertically on Kellys stomach as opposed to horizontally.She said: When we heard her cry out I couldnt believe it. Both Sean and I just burst into tears.We knew it was far from the end of it - but to hear her cry was a huge relief and from that moment we knew she was a fighter.Laurel was born weighing a healthy lb oz, and put straight on a ventilator before being transferred to NICU.She was able to come home after three-and-a-half months.Laurel will soon have the operation to have her organs internalised at the beginning of  and she will have to learn how to breathe again. title: belarus election result president alexander lukashenko
story: President Alexander Lukashenko has been re-elected for a sixth consecutive term in an election that saw his toughest opposition challenge in years.However, there is widespread suspicion that the election was not fair, with two opposition candidates denied places on the ballot before one of them was jailed and the other fled to Russia, Sky News reports.Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, , entered in place of her jailed husband and went on to lead large opposition rallies.But after a state TV exit poll showed Mr Lukashenko was winning .% of the vote, protests broke out.Squares and streets in the capital Minsk were earlier sealed off by police as Mr Lukashenko vowed that the situation would remain under control, BBC News reports.Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko won a landslide re-election victory, the central election commission said today. Figures released by the election commission this morning gave Lukashenko  per cent of the vote.Svetlana Tikhanouskaya, a former English teacher who stood to become Lukashenkos main rival, won . per cent of the vote, the data showed.Tikhanouskaya entered the race after her husband, an anti-government blogger who intended to run, was jailed.Her rallies have drawn some of the biggest crowds since the fall of the Soviet Union in , Reuters reports.The lead-up to the election saw a crackdown on activists and journalists amid the countrys biggest opposition demonstrations in years.After voting on Sunday, Mr Lukashenko said he did not see Ms Tikhanovskaya as a threat, and denied imposing repressive measures on the opposition.Meanwhile, Ms Tsikhanouskaya said she did not believe the polls, saying: I will believe with my own eyes. The majority was for us.There have been clashes between police and thousands of protesters who said the vote was rigged during the night.The protests began after an official exit poll showed that Lukashenko won Sundays presidential election with .% of the vote, securing a sixth term in office.At least one person was killed after being knocked over by a police van and dozens were injured in the clashes that began after polling stations closed on Sunday, a representative of the rights group Spring  told Reuters.Human rights groups say more than , people were detained in the crackdown ahead of the election, including independent election observers and members of Tikhanouskayas campaign team.Some protesters built barricades with rubbish bins, RIA news agency reported. Police fired water cannon, tear gas and stun grenades to disperse the protesters.Interior Ministry spokeswoman Olga Chemodanova said that police efforts to restore order were continuing overnight, according to DW.Alexander Lukashenko, , has been Belarus president since  and has just been re-elected to serve a sixth term.Sometimes referred to as Europes last dictator, President Lukashenko has dismissed his opposition candidate Ms Tikhanovskaya as a poor little girl, manipulated by foreign puppet masters.A former Soviet collective farm manager, Lukashenko has ruled the country since .However, he now faces the biggest challenge in years to keep his grip on power with some voters believing strongly that it is time he stood down.He has cast himself as a guarantor of stability but has battled a wave of anger over his handling of the Covid- pandemic, the economy and his human rights record.Lukashenko has been widely condemned for his handling of the coronavirus pandemic which he said could be treated with saunas and vodka.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc carol kirkwood doggers greenwich park
story: The seasoned weather presenter had been excitedly gushing over the weekends warm weather when she jumbled her words this morning. story: The move comes after Prime Minister said it is the countrys moral duty to get children back in class in England next month.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut it has emerged schools have spent the summer scenario planning for September.It comes just a day after a teachers union was accused of sabotaging the reopening of schools with a nit picking list of  safety demands.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson welcomed a study by Public Health England that shows there is little evidence of Covid- spread in schools.But Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, told the Daily : If you want to limit the number of children on site or travelling to and from school, a big part of that is using rotas and the obvious way to do it is week on-week off.The majority of leadership teams will be thinking about dferent scenarios and how they can get some children to school. title: huge coronavirus study to show
story: NewsHuge coronavirus study to show schools are safe - but its not published yetTory Education Secretary Gavin Williamson has taken the rare step of bigging up an unpublished study on coronavirus in schools - but we wont know what it says until later this yearShareByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  AUG NewsA huge new study will show there is little evidence coronavirus is transmitted in schools, its claimed " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A huge new study will show there is little evidence coronavirus is transmitted in schools, the Tory Education Secretary has claimed.Gavin Williamson said the Public Health England study will be released later this year amid a growing row over plans to send all pupils back full-time in September. But Mr Williamson failed to say when the study, which looked at  educational sites, will be published. A Whitehall source was unable to say whether it would be published before schools are meant to reopen their doors in September. Public Health England was unable immediately to comment on when the report might be released. It comes as the latest figures show Covid- cases rose by , - the largest daily increase in six weeks - amid fears that Britain is on the brink of a second wave. A school union chief today warned schools are losing patience with the demand to have all pupils back in school full-time, with no back-up plan. Mr Williamson said getting all pupils back into school full-time in England is a national priority - while Boris Johnson called it a moral duty. But Geoff Barton, general secretary of the Association of School and College Leaders, said pupils may need to come in on a week on, week off rota. He told the Daily : If you want to limit the number of children on site or travelling to and from school, a big part of that is using rotas and the obvious way to do it is aposweek on, week offapos.  The existence of the study was revealed yesterday by The Sunday Times, which said it was one of the largest in the world on coronavirus in schools. It is being carried out by Public Health England and is said to involve around , pupils and teachers in  schools across England. They were tested to monitor the spread of the disease up to the end of the summer term, according to reports. Usually the government refuses to comment on incomplete or leaked reports. Yet Gavin Williamson yesterday took the extremely rare step of issuing a statement to the media about the study - despite the fact itaposs not been released yet.  He said: The latest research which is expected to be published later this year - one of the largest studies on the coronavirus in schools in the world - makes it clear there is little evidence that the virus is transmitted at school. “There is also growing confidence among parents about their children ing. This is down to the hard work of school staff across the country who are putting in place a range of protective measures to prepare to welcome back all pupils at the start of term.” Professor Russell Viner, president of the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health and a member of Sage, said studies had suggested children were very minor players in the transmission overall of the virus. He told BBC Radio aposs Today programme: There are five studies from around the world from New South Wales, from Australia, Singapore, from Ireland, from Germany, and from France, and in each of those there appears to be very, very little transmission in schools.  We know that children can and do transmit this virus, of course they do, but theyaposre very minor players in the transmission overall, particularly younger children. Itaposs increasingly clear that older children - teenagers probably - transmit as much as adults, but schools themselves play very little role. He added: Thereaposs increasing evidence in the UK and the Government is doing a number of studies which have showed apparently very little transmission and very little infection when schools were open in England. Speaking to BBC Breakfast today, Care Minister Helen Whately insisted “absolutely it’ll be safe. She said: “The evidence that we have is on the one hand of very low transmission and also that the risks to children from Covid are very low. So absolutely it’ll be safe for children to be back in schools, and our national priority is to get to children back in school this autumn.”

The family of tragic Khloe Atkinson said their loved one passed away in her sleep just two days after her rd birthday in the early hours of August . We are stunned, we are heartbroken. The part-time model, from Stoke-on-Trent, had been struck down with a catalogue of medical problems after living with type-one diabetes for  years. In February she suddenly lost the sight in her right eye and a week later was told she had kidney failure. By the time of her death she had been taking  tablets a day and was on dialysis, before being placed in an induced coma at Royal Stoke University Hospital. She previously told  Stoke-on-Trent Live : Diabetes does run in the family - my dad, brother and grandparents all have it.I was diagnosed at the age of  and at that age all of my friends were going out partying, drinking cocktails and I didnapost want to miss out. I just presumed Iaposd put them in incorrectly so I went home to get my glasses and then when I put them on my sight didnapost change.After an emergency appointment I was diagnosed with Macular edema and now have no sight in my right eye and partial sight in my left.About a week later I went to the doctors because I had been experiencing intense  headaches  and nosebleeds.I saw my GP at am one morning and at .pm he called to say I had been playing on his mind and he thought I should seek emergency treatment.  I went to the hospital and was diagnosed with kidney failure. My kidneys are now ing at eight per cent and Iaposve been put on dialysis until I can find a donor. story: NewsSeaside hotel charging whopping £, for £ room - to stop people stayingManager Gary Ricketts of The Kilbirnie in Newquay admitted the price is "crazy" and said they advertised it as that price to stop people booking it as tourists flock for post-lockdown holidaysShareByLee TrewhelaSam Elliott:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsThe AA-certied hotel is ranked  out of  hotels in Newquay on TripAdvisor " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . But the three-star Newquay business has a good reason for the price surge - they actually donapost want anyone to take it.The Kilbirnie, a -bed hotel in the town, advertised a “superior double room with a sea view” on Booking for the huge sum, reports Cornwall Live.It would have set you back over £, on Saturday night - but on the plus side, you could have made a saving on Trivago … of £. Just when you might be thinking they’re trying to make a quick buck out of all the tourists desperate for a post-lockdown break in the sun, click on Expedia and the same room is just £. In a bizarre twist, the hotel is advertising the room at such an exorbitant price to STOP people staying. And the room itself isn’t available anyway – the Kilbirnie is fully booked. Hotel manager Gary Ricketts explained that a glitch in a booking system has meant rooms have been sold to guests via online vendors which aren’t actually available, so this is a move to ensure there are no more disappointed customers. He explained: “Three dferent customers booked rooms through Booking last week and expected to stay here, but we were fully booked. “This is a way of combating that – it’s crazy, no one’s going to pay £, to stay for the night. It’s true that our rates are at a premium, as are everyone’s, but we know no one’s going to pay that amount £ maybe but not £,. “It’s to combat the fact we don’t have any rooms and yet they might appear on the site.” Gary added: “People are seeing these rooms on booking sites and expecting to come to Cornwall but there’s very little availabilityanything everywhere is full. “They’re saying there’s an issue with the system. It’s an issue either on our side or their side. No one can find out what the problem is. “I know of at least two other hotels in Newquay alone that have had this problem. “I’d rather deal with the problem of someone wanting to pay that than someone coming down, expecting to have a room and we haven’t got one. If someone wants to pay over £, they can stay at my house!” He said it wasn’t as simple as just removing the listing as a room at their hotel might still appear available because of the system error.

story: NewsHow Harry Lauder went from poverty to becoming the worlds first superstarHarry – born  years ago this week – became a friend of Hollywood stars and royalty, and the first popular entertainer to get a knighthood. He was born on August ,  in Portobello, EdinburghShareByKeir Mudie:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsSir Harry Lauder was born in  " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . Dont miss our must-read newsletterWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWinston Churchill called Sir Harry Lauder “Scotland’s greatest ever ambassador”. He was the highest-paid performer in the world and the first Brit to sell a million records. Not bad for a lad who worked in a coal mine aged . Arguably Scotland’s greatest ever performer, Harry – born  years ago this week – became a friend of Hollywood stars and royalty, and the first popular entertainer to get a knighthood. But his success was blighted by tragedy when his only son, John, died in  fighting in the First World War. After John’s death, he threw himself into the war effort, raising money for wounded soldiers, and helping to enlist men. And he started the tradition of entertaining the troops at the front, for which he was knighted in . Among Sir Harry’s most popular songs were Roamin’ in the Gloamin, A Wee Deoch-an-Doris and the perennial favourite, I Love a Lassie. Churchill said: “By his inspiring songs and valiant le, [he] rendered measureless service to the Scottish race and to the British Empire.” Sir Harry once said: “Happiness is one of the few things in this world that doubles every time you share it with someone .” He was born Henry McLennan Lauder on August ,  in Portobello, Edinburgh, to mum Isabella and dad John, a skilled potter. Both his parents were from well-connected and well-off families and Harry, the eldest of seven, grew up in relative affluence. In , the family moved to Derbyshire, where John got a job designing porcelain. But shortly after the relocation, he died of pneumonia. Isabella moved the children back to her family in Arbroath in Angus, using John’s £ le insurance to help pay for the journey. Harry, then aged , had to work at a flax mill to help support the family and pay for his education. A couple of years later, they moved in with Harry’s uncle’s family in Hamilton, South Lanarkshire. The three eldest boys became coal miners, an experience Harry said he was “proud” of. He once said of the mines: “I was entombed once for six long hours. It seemed like six years. There were no visible means of getting out.” But there was some light amid the struggle. Harry fell in love with Ann Vallance, the daughter of a colliery manager and the pair wed in June .  As a child, Harry found he had a knack for singing and started performing at school and entering competitions. His first professional appearance came in , and shortly afterwards he joined a concert party that toured Scotland. By the turn of the century, he’d made it to London. Variety magazine said of his first performance in the capital: “In , a Scotch coal miner stood on the street opposite the Tivoli Music Hall. “He had taken a week off to visit London to seek a vaudeville engagement. Before the week was out the miner was booked for  consecutive weeks.” Aged , he had made it. His famous character – kilted, bandy-legged, sentimental, with an eye for a bonnie lass and a wee dram and carrying a knobbly stick – made Scottish culture, or caricature, known the world over. In , Harry undertook the first of  tours of the United States. He made the first of his  recordings in  for The Gramophone Company. Radio was another lucrative medium for Sir Harry – he was once paid £, for one broadcast featuring three of his songs. By the time First World War broke out, Sir Harry was an international star. He sang for the troops, raised funds for the war and soldiers’ charities and formed the Harry Lauder Recruiting Pipe Band which toured Scotland and England. Reports say he convinced more than , men to enlist.  But then tragedy struck when John – a Captain in the th Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders – was killed in action in , in Pozieres, northern France. Sir Harry was told John was shot by a German sniper. Devastated, Harry wrote it had felt like “everything had come to an end” and “the board of le was black and blank”. Anne convinced Harry he should go back on stage, as those who worked on his show relied on him. Three days later, he was back performing. He broke down when he sang The Laddies Who Fought and Won, about boys coming home from the conflict. Archie Foley, a Harry Lauder historian said: “As the curtains closed, he fainted.” During this  tour, he went to the French war cemetery where John was buried. He wrote: “As I lay there on that brown mound, all that he had been, and all that he had meant to me and to his mother came rushing back, opening anew my wounds of grief.

Most babies with the condition have the organs reinserted into their body at birth, but due to the unusually large size of Laurelaposs exomphalos, doctors warned she wouldnapost be able to have them internalised until she is three years old. Laurel was left with a protruding bump from her tiny tummy - which her parents have to wrap in bandages to support her external organs, in case the weight of them were to pull anything  out of her body. Skin has formed around the organs, and Laurel can eat, drink and go to the toilet like any other toddler - but her parents have to keep an eye on their aposdaredevilapos tot, as any injuries to the exomphalos would be irreparable. The mound doesnapost bother the little girl, who loves to cradle her exomphalos when her bandages are removed for bath time, often stroking it and saying aposah tummyapos. Her pouch of organs on her tummy is a part of her and she doesnapost let it get her down. Laurel is a true inspiration and amazes us every day. Laurel and Sean, a car dismantler, were over the moon when they discovered they were expecting their first child in October . We knew sheaposd need the big operation further down the line, but just having her home was so special, Kelly said.  We quickly realised she was an adventurous baby, so knew weaposd need to keep an eye on her so she wouldnapost damage her exomphalos. Surgeons warned the couple thatLaurel damages her external organs, thereaposs nothing they can do - so the family are patiently waiting until Laurel turns three and can have her organs internalised. If inserted into the body too soon, and when her frame is too small, the diaphragm wouldnapost be able to cope with the sudden lack of space with which to operate. story: AdvertorialKids favourite family activity during lockdown revealed by new surveyWith le as we knew it cancelled, people across the UK had to come up with new ways to entertain themselves - and their children - during the coronavirus lockdownShareByZoe ForseyLestyle Editor:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG AdvertorialGardening has become very popular " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIf anyone had told us on New Yearaposs Eve that we would spend the first half of  baking banana bread, doing puzzles and and jumping around the living room to a PE lesson hosted by Joe Wicks, we probably would have simply laughed.But as our Very Big Family Survey - conducted with Very - has proven, lockdown left us all with hours and hours of free time as we were asked to stay indoors to do our tiny bit to save lives.Without school, socialising, clubs, sport and - for some furloughed parents - work, families across the UK needed new ways to keep themselves busy. To fill the time, many people have taken up new hobbies and some families have said their new shared interests have brought them closer together - and they plan to continue them going forward. As the governmentaposs restrictions ease, the Very Big Family Le Survey with Very has looked back at how we all spent the strictest months of lockdown and how people view the “new normal”.Both kids and their parents have the opportunity to do new things, with  per cent of mums and dads with teenage kids saying theyaposve tried something for the first time or more often than normal. Cooking and baking is the most popular aposnewapos activity, with  per cent of parents with teenagers and  per cent of people with younger kids surveyed listing it. Gardening and exercise were next up on the list in both groups. Meanwhile, their kids have also enjoyed cooking and baking, at  per cent, while  per cent have tried their hand at gardening. Arts and crafts and growing their own fruit and veg also made the top five.Interestingly, the exclusive Daily Mirror and Very survey showed that gardening was far lower down the list for kids younger than , with exercise in second place after cooking and baking.Boys were more likely to have spent more time playing a musical instrument and doing DIY. And for many, the group activities have brought them together as a family. Describing the positives of lockdown, one parent wrote: Being able to help more with the kids home schooling as normally I am in work. Building a veg garden and growing our own veg has been a fun thing for all of us.  And I feel we have all grown closer as a family. Meanwhile, other families used the opportunity to exercise and to improve their fitness. Some even opted to do this all together, either through group work outs or by making it a competition. One parent said: Getting myself fitter by running more on my treadmill. The rest of family doing it as well, so we are fitter as a family physically and mentally. Some made the most of their one trip out of the house for exercise by going out for a walk with loved ones. One wrote: Going for a walk with my daughter and spotting all the wildle and breathing cleaner air.Another added: Going out for walks and discovering areas around where I live that I never knew were there. While everyone has obviously faced their own challenges in lockdown, some people have found itaposs also brought some advantages, Veryaposs research found. Parents of younger kids are more likely to have found the lockdown fun compared to those with teenage children, but an incredible amount say the restrictions have brought them closer as a family.

story: NewsMadeleine McCann prime suspect to stay in jail as appeal decision already madeEXCLUSIVE: Christian Brueckner is set to remain in prison as the European Court of Justice has decided his rape conviction was lawful, according to a German politicianShareByRob Hyde:,  AUG Updated:,  AUG NewsChristian Brueckner is set to remain behind bars after the ECJs decision, it is claimed " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe European Court of Justice has already decided on a ruling meaning the Madeleine McCann prime suspect will not be released early from prison, a German politician has said.  Germany is treating the Maddie case as a murder investigation, with convicted paedophile Christian Brueckner, , the chief suspect.Brueckner is currently in prison in the northern German city of Kiel for drugs offences. Now, in an exclusive interview, Ulrich Watermann, , the parliamentary groupaposs spokesman on domestic policy for the Social Party of Germanyin Lower Saxony, says the European Court of Justicehas already made a decision which will ultimately keep Brueckner behind bars.The Mirror previously reported on how the ECJaposs Advocate General advised that Brueckneraposs seven-year sentence for rape should stand. The Advocate Generalaposs recommendation is non-binding although it is usually a strong indication of a subsequent decision. Watermann has now claimed the ECJ has followed the advice, with the official ruling set to be announced later this week.Brueckner’s defence team has appealed a seven-year sentence he received for the rape of a -year-old American woman in . Watermann, however, says the ECJ has already decided that the rape conviction was lawful, meaning Brueckner will be kept in prison for seven years to serve this sentence.“To the best of my knowledge the decision has already been made relating to a conviction of a rape of an American woman, and this was conviction was found to be in accordance with European law. Therefore, he [Brueckner] will remain in jail not only for the drugs, but also for the rape. Lawyers defending Brueckner had appealed against the rape conviction which he was handed in December  at the regional court of Braunschweig, Lower Saxony.  German police had extradited Brueckner to Germany via a European arrest warrant in  in connection with an earlier sex offence against a minor. His lawyers then claimed it was against the rules for German prosecutor to later try Brueckner for rape, as this was not the crime he was officially extradited for.   When the case was taken to the German supreme court, the Federal Court of Justice , the court decided to seek further clarication from the ECJ on the laws governing European arrest warrants.   Here Brueckner’s defence team had claimed the European arrest warrant’s principle of speciality protected a person being extradited one crime then having to stand trial for another.  Last week, however, a preliminary opinion by the ECJ’s advocate general, Michal Bobek, found that Brueckner had been lawfully tried for rape.   Bobek’s ruling is not binding, as the ECJ now has to officially announce its own ruling. But Ulrich Watermann says this has already been made behind closed doors.He said this means the public prosecution office in Braunschweig, which is leading the Maddie investigation, no now longer needs to find a reason to keep Brueckner in prison.   “This means they can calmly continue the investigation, which has been started so intensively. I hope that the case will be solved so that Maddie’s parents can close a terrible chapter, but despite this the pain will remain.”   “I hope that there will also be a conviction, as a deterrent to prevent other such crimes from taking place.”  Lower Saxony and the neighbouring state of North-Rhine Westphalia both became the focus of recent media attention when German cyber police units uncovered large paedophile networks.   At the end of June, some , suspects were investigated in Bergisch Gladbach, and just weeks earlier  suspects had been arrested in Remscheid in connection with a nationwide child sex abuse ring.   Following the scandal in Bergisch Gladbach, the ministry of justice in North Rhine Westphalia said “We want to drag perpetrators and supporters of child abuse out of the anonymity of the internet.” For Watermann, however, politicians need to go much further.   “There should be a thorough and intensive consultation on how we can find means to drain this swamp, to make it as dficult as possible, or to stop such violence against children being committed altogether.”  We have to realize that -we do not put child protection before data protection - we have no chance to investigate such cases.”  Meanwhile Watermann says the Maddie case has provided the impulse to push for a reform of Germany’s legal framework to fight child abuse on the internet.   He claims that the German constitution, written in , must now be revised to reflect the digital age, and make the protection of children more important than data protection.  “The Maddie case has provided the impulse for a nationwide debate about rethinking our entire approach to protecting children. There have been ious changes made to our laws already, including banning sex dolls – and I’m for all of this, but we cannot just have superficial soundbites, we need a deeper, more major, thorough reform, and we need to amend our constitution.”  “Today there is sometimes almost a lawless situation online whereby paedophiles thrive and hide online. This must change so that whatever you do online is punished asit was offline.”  Lower Saxony and the neighbouring state of North-Rhine Westphalia both became the focus of recent media attention when German cyber police units uncovered giant paedophile networks.   At the end of June, some , suspects were investigated in Bergisch Gladbach, and just weeks earlier  suspects had been arrested in Remscheide in connection with a nationwide child sex abuse ring.   Following the scandal in Bergisch Gladbach, the ministry of justice in North Rhine Westphalia said “We want to drag perpetrators and supporters of child abuse out of the anonymity of the internet.” For Watermann, however, politicians need to go much further.   “There should be a thorough and intensive consultation on how we can find means to drain this swamp, to make it as dficult as possible, or to stop such violence against children being committed.”  “In the past paedophile networks would all meet at one location, such as a camping site, and commit their horric acts there, but now in the digital age they don’t need to take these risks. They can just meet online. Our constitution needs to reflect this.”  “We need to catch-up quickly, not have laws which are relevant for the past. It is important police can all physical evidence, but also everything that is available in the digital world. We need to discuss how this material can also be used in the future. We have to realize thatwe put child protection before data protection then we have no chance to identy such cases.”  Germany has the strictest data protections regulations in the EU, and for years, in Germany, the inidual’s right to have his or her data protected has widely been viewed as almost sacrosanct.   Much of this is a side-effect of having lived under two violently oppressive regimes. Under the Third Reich, the Nazi’s used intensive and horric surveillance of the German population to identy and persecute Jews, gypsies, communists, homosexuals and other minorities.   After the defeat of Nazism in , Germany made a concerted effort to limit the amount of personal data which authorities were allowed to gather, and develop laws around this.   The world’s very first data protection law was passed in  in Hessen, part of the former West Germany. Just seven years later came the Federal Data Protection Act, which aimed to protect West German citizens against abuse in the “storage, transmission, modication and deletion” of private data.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA metal detectorist has discovered a hoard of Bronze Age artefacts in the Scottish Borders which experts have described as nationally signicant. Mariusz Stepien was searching a field near Peebles with friends on June  when he found a bronze object buried half a metre underground. The group camped in the field and built a shelter to protect the find from the elements while archaeologists spent  days investigating. Among the items found were a complete horse harness - preserved by the soil - and a sword which have been dated as being from  to  BC. Mr Stepien said: I thought Iaposve never seen anything like this before and felt from the very beginning that this might be something spectacular and Iaposve just discovered a big part of Scottish history. I was over the moon, actually shaking with happiness. We wanted to be a part of the excavation from the beginning to the end. I will never forget those  days spent in the field. Every day there were new objects coming out which changed the context of the find, every day we learned something new.  Iaposm so pleased that the earth revealed to me something that was hidden for more than  years. I still canapost believe it happened. As he was getting strong signals from the earth around the initial object, Mr Stepien contacted the Treasure Trove Unit to report his find.  They also found decorated straps, buckles, rings, ornaments and chariot wheel axle caps. Evidence of a decorative rattle pendant from the harness was also discovered - the first one to be found in Scotland and only the third in the UK. The hoard has been moved from the site in a large block of soil and taken to the National Museums Collection Centre in Edinburgh.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mum weighs just five-and-a-half stone after eating nothing but chicken nuggets for four years. Michaela Harris, , says just the sight of any other food, except crisps, is enough to make her gag. The mum-of-three has gorged on the nuggets, which have to be battered and bought from Iceland, after her relationship fell apart in . She stopped eating after the split and lost two-and-a-half stone in three months, with her weight dropping to five stone. Michaela, of Middlesbrough, Teesside, finally managed to start consuming chicken nuggets, however she still avoids other foods and only weighs five-and-a-half stone. Now she’s worried her kids three children, Isabella, seven, Jacob, five, and one-year-old Isla Rose will start to copy her habit. She said: “I really worry that the kids will start copying me. My youngest is a fussy eater already. Itaposs my biggest fear that sheaposs got it from me. The stay-at-home mum was diagnosed with avoidant restrictive food intake disorder , an extreme form of fussy eating, in , following the dficult breakup. She had a normal diet until the split and particularly enjoyed full English breakfasts. She added: “I went through a tough breakup and I stopped eating anything at all, Iaposd just have a can of Monster for breakfast.  There were a few other things I ate but only really small amounts. I lost two and a half stone in three months. I was around five stone then eventually I moved onto chicken nuggets. I just wish I could eat more and a bigger iety. Iaposd love to be chubby, it looks great. My partner suggested going on holiday next year and it terries me.”  Michaela is thankful her partner, John Docherty, , has supported her throughout her condition. However, she is concerned about her young kids and that she may lose her sight, a common prognosis of ARFID. The mother continued: “The thought of my babies growing up without me because of my food phobia is terrying. If I lose my sight, I know that Iaposll have the best people who love me and help me adjust. My biggest fear is that Iaposll go downhill and lose weight again to a point that I canapostfrom. Before, there wasnapost anything I didnapost like and Iaposd eat pretty much anything. Iaposd eat three slices of bacon, two eggs, four sausages, two pieces of fried toast, three hash browns and beans in one sitting.  I could really put some food away. Iaposm trying really hard to add new foods into my diet now. John spends most of the day asking meI fancy this or that, he will travel quite far sometimes when I want something but canapost find any, he will hunt that thing down.” In fact, Michaela considers her spouse her superhero for his time and patience. Without John I wouldnapost be here. He is constantly trying to encourage me and make me feel good about myself, telling me Iaposm doing really well evenIaposve only eaten three or four strawberries,” she added.  He is always keeping an eye on my moods, he notices when Iaposm slipping with food and will then up his attempts to get me eating again. What he does goes above what any sort of paid carer would do for me. He cooks for me pretty much most of the time because I canapost stand to smell my food too much before eating it as it can make me feel really sick. Heaposs stood with me for hours at a time trying to think of something I will eat, he goes to the ends of the earth to help me.

This blunder has been called out by TV personality Te Hamua Nikora, who is Māori.In a video shared to his Facebook page, he said: Some people call it appreciation, I call it appropriation. Use your own language.The video went viral, being watched over , times.Thousands of people also commented on the post, with many finding the companyaposs error amusing. One person said: This is fricken gold. Iaposm not even Maori and I know what it means. Another wrote: I canapost even. Others branded the man a legend for making the video. title: dundee fc kevin mcdonald dundee united brechin celtic
story: He’s graced the English Premier League and sampled international football.But former Dundee midfielder Kevin McDonald says his path to stardom wouldn’t have been possible without humble beginnings in Brechin.The -year-old will play in England’s top-flight once more next season after the Cottagers’ play-off final win over Brentford on Tuesday night.Speaking on the Open Goal podcast, the Scotland and Fulham ace credited his exposure to first-team football with the Dee as a major factor in his rise.He made his full Dark Blues debut at Glebe Park as a -year-old back in  and has since turned out for the likes of Burnley, Sheffield United and Wolves.McDonald racked up  appearances for Dundee, scoring  goals, before leaving three years after his senior bow and looks back at his time at Dens Park fondly.The Carnoustie-born player also lted the lid on a rejection from Dundee United and says it inspired him to make the grade at their city rivals.He said: “I got bombed from Dundee United early doors. They said I was too small after youth team level.“Usually it’s a case of, ‘He’s too small,’ being an easy excuse but I was about ft  when I was !“I was gone then, thinking my career was done before it had even started but luckily enough I got picked up by Dundee.“It went quite quick from there. I played a few U-s games, established myself and had a good season.“When they were short of players for the reserves I’d come up and join them sitting on the bench.“Luckily enough I managed to come on for a couple of games, done well and just managed to build my way up.“Next minute there was a few injuries in the first team and boys not wanting to play and I was making my full debut at Brechin away.“I was like here we go, Brechin away for my debut. I remember walking into the changing-room thinking to myself, ‘I’m buzzing,’ but looking back now I question why!“It was fantastic, though, and my career has took off since then.”One man who McDonald feels should take particular credit for his success is ex-Dee gaffer Alex Rae.Former Rangers midfielder Rae replaced Alan Kernaghan in the Dens dugout in  as player-manager and McDonald initially feared for his midfield position.He added: “I knew straight away I was done but he’s the manager at the end of the day so I was still young and ready to accept it.“He came in and he was at it. He put himself straight into a reserve game and, to be fair to him, he was absolutely brilliant.“He was a player and absolutely battered us. He was the biggest signing for Dundee when I was there.“It was such a high-profile player and manager to have besides all the Italians.“When he came in it was a bit of a wake-up call because he raised the standard as such.“He was quite hard on people but it was what the club needed at the time.“He was hard on me because he could see I had potential to go on to another levelI wanted to.“He was the same with Robbo , DickerandSwankie – the lot of them.“He helped me, to be fair, because he was a centre midfielder he helped me massively.“He was smashing people in training on a daily basis. Normally managers want you to take care in training a little bit but he was wanting you to go in hard.“If you were pulling out of a tackle, he was hammering you so it got feisty at times but he loved that everyone was playing hard for their places.“He brought that mentality to the club.”McDonald began to establish himself in Rae’s side, rejecting interest from Celtic and Everton, before moving to Burnley for £,.He was a standout in Scotland’s second tier but not at any point did he find it easy.McDonald said: “After a couple of goals you do gain a bit of confidence and then there’s the media hype and that.“It did start to feel easier as time went on. The more I played, the more I got into it and felt more comfortable.“I’d never at the time say it was easy when you’re going to places like Airdrie away and they’re absolutely battering you.”Of the transfer interest, he added: “I’d see so many people and heard so many stories of people going to Celtic and being a number.“They had a -man squad, some incredible players right the way through their set-up, such strength and depth throughout the whole club.“I had a chat with my agent and family and said I don’t think I fancy going there at all.“I knew there was a couple of clubs interested down south still. That was the swaying point and I thought I needed to give it a blast and go there.“I had the choice of Burnley and Everton and went to Burnley. I don’t know how that one worked out to be honest.“It was Owen Coyle who sold it in the end. title: dundee fc st mirren danny mullen calum woodger
story: It was a case of out with the old and in with the new for Dundee’s strike force this week – whether that’s for better or worse, only time will tell.Kane Hemmings’ departure from the club will have shocked some dark blues given previous signs he’d be sticking around at Dens Park.As it transpired, the English hitman saw his future where, backing out of a pay-cut deal as he seeks pastures new.The -year-old, of course, is well within his rights to do so but it is still a blow for the Dee.Last term saw him notch  goals and, as his performances improved with each passing game, there was a sense Hemmings had more to give in the coming campaign.We’ll never knowhe would’ve hit the heights of his first spell at the club, where he scored  goals for Premiership Dundee in  . But that’s OK.Yes, Hemmings is almost definitely a better goal-scorer and probably a greater all-round player than his replacements but he doesn’t want to be with the Dark Blues and Danny Mullen and Alex Jakubiak do.Having watched them extensively at St Mirren in recent times, their commitment to the cause, I believe, will be immediately evident to Dundee fans.Mullen, in particular, is a passionate sort.He performs best when riled and up against it, his energy seemingly endless and with a phenomenal work-rate to boot.Prolic he is not but he is good for a goal, and no stranger to a wonder strike.The -year-old former Livingston man loves being in the final third, gets his team up the park and is surprisingly good in the air despite not being the tallest frontman.Of course, a lot of this is known to Dees, with Mullen scoring three times against them in their   relegation season.The nippy forward also bagged a crucial goal against city rivals Dundee United in the Premiership Play-off Final that term, proving he can be a man for the big occasion.A lot of Buddies fans were disappointed to see Mullen let go but their loss is the Dark Blues’ gain.He could make all the dference in getting Dundee back into the top flight.Jakubiak, too, was a favourite among the Paisley faithful and a serious target for boss Jim Goodwin.His wage demands proved too much for St Mirren so it is curious to see him at the Dee.His quality is without question, however, and paired with Mullen they may just fill Hemmings’ void.They might not have made the best start to the season but Motherwell should be the benchmark for Dundee United.Going by last term’s standings, outwith the Old Firm, ’Well are the Premiership’s top side.Despite their opening day - defeat at Ross County on Monday night, Stephen Robinson’s side hold a title United should be aiming for – the best of the rest.Third is the most anyone in Scottish football can realistically hope for with the big two from Glasgow about.And why not the Tangerines  They are one of Scottish football’s biggest and most historic clubs after all.Hearts would usually lay a claim to being Scotland’s third power but, with the Jambos now in the Championship, it’s open for a few others.Aberdeen and Hibs would be the other obvious candidates but the Steelmen have shown what can be achieved on a smaller budget.Whatever the result is at Fir Park today, the Terrors shouldhome inspired to lay claim to ’Well’s unofficial crown.The myth of English football exceptionalism persists.This week it was the wholly unexceptional Jamie O’Hara bumming up the Premier League while laying into our game at the same time.The former Tottenham midfielder claimed relegated Bournemouth would be a bigger job than European football with Rangers for Steven Gerrard.Utter nonsense. title: dundee united sporting director tony asghar urges fans not to ask for selfies or autographs
story: Dundee United sporting director Tony Asghar has pleaded with fans to keep their distance from players as the club copes with the coronavirus crisis.Prompted or not by the drama in Aberdeen, which has seen the Dons’ match against St Johnstone in Perth postponed, the Tangerines have urged supporters to refrain from asking for autographs and selfies.Ahead of the Tannadice club’s trip to Motherwell tomorrow, Asghar said: “With the football season under way, we still all have exceptional challenges to endure with Covid- and the safety of our whole community is paramount.“The club has worked tirelessly, and with great expense, to adhere to restrictions and measures implemented from the SFA SPFL Joint Response Group to make sure our players, coaches and performance staff are tested twice a week and conform to all medical advice to be able to train and play matches.“Our hope is that by doing this in the short term, we will soon see supporters at matches and players will eventuallyto a normal working environment.“However, I must stress that it is important that our fans support us during this time.“Over the past few weeks, there have been attempts made to approach players at the High-Performance Centreat the University of St Andrews to sign shirts and take selfies.“This is not acceptable and could seriously jeopardise the health of the players and also impact on the continuation our competitive matches.“Your support is fundamental to our players and staff but, at this present time, we cannot have anyone other than players and staff attending the HPC or the stadium on match days or approaching the players until we have clear indications of a change in the process.“Our players and staff are well aware of the ramications of this virus but they also find it dficult to turn down an advance of a fan as is human nature, especially for the type of player we have at Dundee United,” added Asghar.“However, I also know the core support of Dundee United FC will also adhere to this, so please spread the word to others.
