title: musselburgh-rugby-club-beer-garden-offers-safe-place
story: Members and guests were welcomed to the large outdoor space which has been created at its grounds at Stoneyhill.The beer garden and lsquoPickerings Patiorsquo ndash named after one of the clubrsquos main sponsors Pickerings Gin ndash is offering them a safe space to visit as the lockdown eases.A club spokesperson said: ldquoWe hope it will be a welcome facility for the local community and a permanent feature as the club moves into its centenary year in .ldquoThe club has done a lot of work getting familiar with all of the Covid government and council guidance, including full risk assessments and ensuring all staff have appropriate PPE.ldquoWe have installed sanitisers at key posts around the club and have an increased cleaning system for our toilet and bar facilities, as well as introducing systems in the bar and toilets which implement social distancing.The spokesperson added: ldquoWe really enjoyed welcoming back members and guests to our new outdoor space which we have worked hard to make sure is a safe area, given we have the luxury to use a lot of space outside the club.ldquoWe recognise peoplersquos levels of comfort will be very dferent coming outof lockdown and want to ensure we offer a safe place to visit, while also offering some form of normality, as the club has always been a welcoming and fun place to visit.ldquoThe staff have been doing a great job and we recognise it is still a learning curve for everyone, including guests.ldquoWe are looking to adapt to opening insidewe have to address any poor weather but this brings restrictions and will be thought out in more detail moving forward.The beer garden and Pickerings Patio is open Fridays pm-pm, Saturdays noon-pm and Sundays pm-pm.While walk-ins are welcome, subject to availability, bookings are recommended at the Eventbrite link via www.musselburghrfc

title: schools-planning-soft-start-new-term
story: Pupils across the county face changes as theyto school with increased emphasis on hand hygiene, staggered breaks and lunch times and no assemblies or even indoor PE initially.And they will be told to wear face masks on all home to school transport after East Lothian Council took the decision to introduce the rule across the board with exceptions for additional support learning pupils and those with medical exemptions.Primary school staff are writing to parents outlining changes to the school day which will see them asked to say goodbye to their children at school gates and youngsters barred from playing or mixing with friends in other classes initially, as they are kept in class clusters.While youngsters are not expected to social distance in schools, teaching staff will have to maintain a safe distance. In primary schools, changes include children being kept in their own class group during break times and lunch times instead of being allowed to mix with other youngsters, staggered starts and requests for parents of older children P- not to come into the playground with them in the mornings but to remain at school gates.East Lothian MSP Iain Gray welcomed the youngstersrsquoto schools with a special thought for those starting school for the first time.He said: ldquoTheof pupils to school is the biggest, and most important move out of lockdown yet.ldquoGood luck to all of the countyrsquos pupils and teachers as they finally get back to face to face learning.ldquoAs a grandad with two grandchildren starting school for the first time, I am thinking especially of those new P pupils.ldquoI know that teachers, cleaners, janitors, classroom assistants and our local education department have worked incredibly hard for this day, to ensure that schools can restart safely.ldquoThey were not helped by the government telling them to plan for social distancing in the classroom, and then suddenly being told thewould be full time ndash but I have every confidence that they will have turned that round.ldquoI know that many parents will have mixed feelings, pleased that their children are going back to school, because home schooling has been tough for all families, but anxious for their childrenrsquos safety too.ldquoIt is important that everything needed is in place ndash sanitiser, testing, and, in senior years social distancing where possible. Everyone has a part to play in sticking by the rules, and I am sure that here in East Lothian, they will.Kenny MacAskill, East Lothian MP, said thewas a ldquowelcome but a watchful one.He said: ldquoIt wonrsquot be easy for either staff or pupils and care needs taken. But making a start is essential for young people and our county. Good luck and we must all do what we can to help.Headteachers at all six secondary schools have contacted parents and carers to outline a phasedwhich, instead of seeing all pupilswhen the schools officially open on Wednesday, will see them come back gradually. Five of the countyrsquos six secondary schools ndash Knox Academy, Dunbar Grammar School, North Berwick High School, Ross High School and Preston Lodge High School ndash will all follow the same phased timetable.Primary schools across East Lothian are writing to parents this week with details of how youngsters willnext week and changes to their usual routines.At Dunbar Primary School, P, P and P only attend on Wednesday, August , with only P, P and P attending on Thursday, August , with all in on Friday, August .Those pupils, parents and carers have been told on those days the soft start will mean pupils should arrive between .am to .am and instead of lining up will walk into the playground and be greeted by a member of the support staff.They will walk them into their class, then they will wash their hands under the supervision of their class teacher.Headteacher Helen Gillanders told parents: ldquoThis means that parents and pupils will need to say lsquogoodbyersquo at the main school gates rather than coming into the main playground.ldquoWe appreciate this is dferent but we are looking to manage the safety of pupils and staff and reduce the contact with adults from dferent households.Leaving times will be staggered and parents and carers asked to wait at the school gates with teachers dismissing pupils as they identy their relative.Primary  pupils at Dunbar PS will see half attend on the Wednesday and the other half on the Thursday, with a start time of am to .am and again parents and carers will be asked to say goodbye at the school gate with teaching staff taking the new pupils into class.Families are being encouraged to practise the lsquokiss and hug goodbyersquo routine with youngsters ahead of their school start date with staff on hand to support them on the day.Some primary schools, including Sandersonrsquos Wynd in Tranent, are welcoming all pupils back on Wednesday, August , with staggered times for starting and finishing their school days.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoA small number of our primary schools are operating a phased start at the beginning of the new academic session, in line with Scottish Government guidance.ldquoThe priority is to bring children back safely and to establish good hygiene protocols in our larger schools. Consideration has also been given to the transition experience for primary  pupils and for young people moving in to S.

title: renegade-street-sweepers-bid-spruce-town
story: Called the Musselburgh Renegade Street Sweepers, it aims to meet up on a weekly basis to take on sprucing up parts of the Honest Toun by litter picking, weeding, cleaning and general tidying up.The initiative was launched following the efforts of environment group Love Musselburgh CIC whose volunteers took on the task of painting picnic tables with seats near the Promenade.Michael Philp, of Fisherrow, who set up Musselburgh Renegade Street Sweepers, said: ldquoI set up the group to seewe could start to arrange regular volunteer work groups to go out and do little weeding jobs and tidying up the area. I thought it would be a good thing to have a separate group of people happy to help and to concentrate on what we could do as a community rather than things we canrsquot.A Facebook page was created and has already attracted more than  members.Mr Philp said he has already been out to do some weeding around a few of the benches on the Promenade, adding: ldquoI hope we can inspire others to come and help with little projects.He said: ldquoHopefully this group will grow.ldquoWe have no money or tools yet, apart from maybe tools lying in the shed or garage, but what we have is determination and passion to make change, do things together to fix and mend what might be broken.ldquoI came to Musselburgh as a child in  and itrsquos suffered like many, many towns up and down the UK with cutbacks to many services.ldquoWe can sit and talk and debate about whorsquos to blame and say who should be doing this and who should be doing that, but it doesnrsquot solve things, so I thought we could do some little bits.ldquoOthers are doing it in other local towns with great success. Irsquod like people to post up things that they feel need attention and we will seewe can get a plan together and get some things sorted.Melanie Roccio, who set up Love Musselburgh, is supporting the group.She said: ldquoIt would be great to hear from everybody about any streets or areas around town you have noticed are in need of a little bit of TLC. Is there some overgrown shrubbery that could do with being cut back, something that could do with a fresh coat of paint or some graffiti that needs cleaned To sign up for the Musselburgh Renegade Street Sweepers, go to www.facebook groups   refshareCouncillor Andy Forrest, Depute Provost of East Lothian, said: ldquoThis is a very welcome initiative for the town which reflects the pride many local residents have for Musselburgh. The council is always keen to support such endeavours and encourage similar groups who volunteer to enhance their local environment.Fellow ward member Councillor Katie Mackie commented: ldquoItrsquos really appreciated that local residents are volunteering to help keep Musselburgh tidy. Civic pride is important and hopefully this group can supplement the routine street cleaning and waste disposal work done by East Lothian Councilrsquos hard working waste workers. Itrsquos important there is a coordinated approach between the group and the council, and I would be happy to help facilitate thisit is required.Finally, Councillor John Williamson said: ldquoThe Musselburgh Renegade Street Sweepers is the latest in a number of initiatives in Musselburgh which demonstrate the growing pride in our town and a determination to make it a better place for everyone. Their work tidying and weeding at the benches on the Promenade demonstrates how easy and quick it is to make a vast improvement to an area. I wish them well with their efforts in the future and hope to be able to join in myself at some point.

title: action-packed-virtual-musselburgh-festival-proves-huge-success
story: Although the election of the  Honest Lad and Honest Lass, and the festival itself, were cancelled due to the Covid- pandemic, the local community enjoyed reminiscing about past events.The Honest Tounrsquos Association, which organises the annual festival, was determined to keep the spirit of the event alive while keeping everyone safe.Two films were shown via the associationrsquos Facebook page and Twitter feed. The first, about Kirkinrsquo Sunday, was available for viewing on what would have been Kirkinrsquo Sunday ndash July . The other was about Festival Saturday, which was shown at the end of the lsquovirtualrsquo programme on July .Festival flags were delivered to local residents by association representatives to put up outside their homes ndash a gesture which may continue for future festivals.During lockdown, photos of previous festivals from the associationrsquos archives were posted on social media and this continued during lsquovirtualrsquo festival week, with popular events in the programme displayed.A virtual fancy dress parade took place, with members of the public invited to submit photos of themselves in fancy dress at home or in past parades.The virtual dog show was a roaring success, attracting more than  entries from owners who sent in photos of their pets in  classes, giving judges Gordon Vets a dficult task.Kennedy Bosworth won the most unusual place you have found your dog categoryAnother highlight was a virtual concert co-ordinated by Julie Robinson, Honest Lass . The musical extravaganza was compegravered by Caroline Grant, Honest Lass , and saw performances from the Clark Community Choir, Tutti Orchestra, Douglas McNeill, Lorraine McBrearty, Reno Di Rolloand Fiona Grant-MacDonald.Alison Elgin, president of the Honest Tounrsquos Association, said: ldquoThe virtual festival went very, very well. People enjoyed reminiscing about years gone by.ldquoThere were lots of positive and supportive comments and feedback.She added that the coronavirus lockdown had enabled the association to develop an extensive archive of old photos and videos and added that a lsquovirtualrsquo event could run alongside future festivals.

title: hairless-bikers-clocking-thousands-miles-charity
story: David Jones, , of Pencaitlandrsquos Limekilns, has joined his best friend of more than  years Trevor Kerr, , who lives in Manchester, in a trip that will see them visit as many European countries as possible.They will travel , to , miles over  days.David left for the trip on Sunday, with the pair meeting at the Channel Tunnel to go to France on Monday.He said: ldquoWe want to have fun but raise a bit of awareness and collect a bit of money along the way.The pair did not plan where they were going or where they would stay, simply booking a hotel where and when it was needed.They are former colleagues and worked together at Davidrsquos advertising company Cool Billboards Ltd, a business he sold after the death of his we Amanda to stomach cancer in February last year. Amanda had been diagnosed in November  and given  weeks to live.David and Trevor are raising money for Pancreatic Cancer UK after Trevor was diagnosed with an aggressive form of the condition in November last year,  months after Amanda.His diagnosis is terminal and he has received  chemotherapy sessions.Trevor was also given  weeks to live but chose to go through treatment to extend his le.He is receiving more treatment in September.This is not the first time that the pair have embarked on a tour like this and it was this previous trip that inspired them to go again.In Christmas , David received a present to go on a motorbike ride and the following February he left with Trevor to go on a -day tour around Europe.However, they were on their trip during the Beast from the East snowstorm of early , which saw them ride through snow in mainland Europe.David, who owns a couple of coffee shops in London, said: ldquoWe went through the Swiss Alps, France and Italy and people were following us through France and beeping their horns at us, so we said thatwe ever do this again that we must do it for charity.The pair then set up their own website, called the Hairless Bikers www.hairlessbikers, inspired by lsquoHairy Bikersrsquo David Myers and Si King with their own twist, as both David and Trevor are bald.The pair were planning their next trip until Amandarsquos terminal diagnosis, with David saying the news came ldquoall of a sudden.After Amandarsquos death, David spent time dealing and coming to terms with his loss and then Trevor received his diagnosis.And when the coronavirus pandemic started earlier this year, it added to an already dficult year.The pair were waiting for Trevor to finish his chemotherapy before starting the tour, with Trevor phoning David last month and askinghe wanted to go.David told the Courier before he set off: ldquoWersquove always said we will do it but now itrsquos all go.ldquoTrevor phoned me last weekend and said: lsquoLetrsquos just do it.rsquo If we donrsquot do it now then itrsquos never going to happen.ldquoWe thought about all of the news going on at the moment andanything happens or we need to come back we are just in Europe so can easily catch a plane home.Ahead of the trip, David said he was ldquovery excited, adding he was just going to focus on riding and see what happened.He added: ldquoWe wonrsquot stop laughing, wersquoll be like little kids.An initial target of pound was raised, with more than pound, raised in a few days.David saidan average of pound a day could be raised ldquothat will be brilliant.Donate at www.facebook donate

title: column-tory-disarray-not-reassuring
story: It cannot be reassuring for the Scottish Tories that their leader has only been in the position since February and has now left the party in disarray.It is clear the party do not hold Scottish Parliament seats in a high regard, given that it is looking likely that the next leader will be Douglas Ross, who is not even currently an MSP.Scottish Parliament seats require a member who is willing to commit time and effort to their constituency, they are not simply a stepping stone for jumping into a leadership bid.If you compare the Toriesrsquo leadership with that of Nicola Sturgeon over the last few months, with her clear and consistent messaging throughout the Covid- crisis, it is easy to see why polls for the SNP and independence are through the roof.I know that many are looking forward to enjoying the Eat Out to Help Out scheme, which will offer discounts of up to  per cent at restaurants and cafeacutes throughout August.I welcome this help for local businesses, and I am sure that this will benefit them in their restarts following lockdown.I would like to stress, however, that guidelines should always be followed within these establishments.That means that you should be socially distancing from those who are not from your household or extended household, and you should maintain good hygiene by regularly washing your hands for  seconds, as well as not touching your face.To keep yourself safe, it is important to use businesses that are taking these measures seriously and putting safety precautions in place to protect their customers.This week I will be hosting the first meeting of the Esk River Improvement Group.I look forward to working with them to make progress towards cleaning up the Esk.

title: tims-tales-mist-midges-memories
story: Oh and I forgot to mention the midges, which add a particularly Highland flavour to any camping trip up north.Such was our experience last weekend after we managed to find a campsite that was open. We managed just one overnight stay in Glen Nevis.It has always been a favourite glen of mine.Its beauty challenges the majestic Glencoe, but its landscape is gentler and less rugged, and the upper reaches of the glen take you back in time, to the majesty of the ancient Caledonian forest.In the days when I was a tour guide, I always thought that mist and rain were an essential part of a trip to the Highlands.People would refer to hot and sunny weather as good weather, but Irsquod always say that in the Highlands mist and rain can be good weather too.On such days, the weather would add the veil of mystery and unpredictability that makes the landscape so intriguing.Hardly ever was the approach to Glencoe the same because of the weather it changes the landscape in ways the imagination could never predict.Swirling mists which dress the peaks, layers of low lying cloud which suddenly break to allow sparkling rays of sunshine itrsquos spine-tinglingly magical.On days of so called good weather, when the skies were a cloudless blue, I always felt there was something missing in the experience.I know all this might sound like patter from VisitScotland attempting to persuade rain drenched tourists that they are lucky to have experienced the true mystery of our country but for me it has always been true.Of course, days of endless pelting rain are no fun and can spoil a holiday, but for me, some mist and rain, in moderation, makes a Highland holiday all the more memorable.Such was our experience last weekend, with two days that seemed to be in dferent seasons.When we arrived we were lucky to be able to put up the tent just in time, before the rain got heavy.Itrsquos always an awkward moment for me putting up our tent in full view of other campers, as we struggle to remember which pole goes where and try not to look like we need assistance.It couldrsquove been easy to be despondent at the weather. Dark brooding clouds shrouded the sides of Ben Nevis, bringing rain that threatened to dampen everything but I refused to let it dampen our spirits.I recited the famous quote: ldquoIn Scotland there is no such thing as bad weather just bad clothing.We had a hearty camp stove meal and then set off for our walk in the Nevis Gorge.Itrsquos a well kent walk now, but when I was first taken many years ago before the internet it was a relatively unknown secret. I still remember the sense of awe as I heard the roar of the river below, and the sight of the distant waterfall An Steall as we emerged from the gorge.Our trick was to go on our walk when it was raining, and after teatime so we had the place almost to ourselves, well apart from the midges.Our midge repellent was gold dust, and Irsquove always found the trick in avoiding midges is to keep moving, which we did, except for once, and we momentarily paid the price.It was a walk in the childhood footsteps of my younger self, where my young children were re-pacing along the route also taken by their older siblings years ago.It was about saying ldquohere is a place important to me, part of who I am itrsquos yours now,you want it to be.Yet not saying it with words, but by making memories that I hope will last as long as mine have.The rain and mist was all part of it, and yes even the midges. As often happens, the weather began to clear as we headed back.The sun broke through and the clouds developed a sparkling yellow tint. The mountains appeared, like giants awoken and rising to their true height.Sunshine briefly warmed our faces and it seemed a gt from the gods for our endurance.The kids danced and sang the song ldquoI can see clearly now the rain has gone as they saw a rainbow.I knew the rain hadnrsquot really gone so we didnrsquot dally.We made it back to the car, tired with sore legs, but before the next dark cloud arrived.That evening we recounted our experiences in the tent, and I told stories about the Jacobites and the old Highland way of le, and the connection to the Battle of Prestonpans on our own doorstep.The kids listened, partly because we were camping and they had no screens, so no choice but Irsquod like to believe partly also because we were in a land where stories and legends are steeped in the soil and they now felt a small part of them.It lashed with rain all night. But its rage had ended by morning and the new day welcomed us with sunshine.New adventures beckoned, with other memories to impart, on what was to become our sunny day.Loch Oich, rich in family memory and where the ashes of both my parents were scattered.Then Loch Ness, a fitting end to a pilgrimage, especially for my monster daft wee boy, and his sisters who love the mystery of the story.Such was our short ldquostaycation this summer.Wersquod followed what I have always called The Road of Legends which is the title of my yet to be published novel, an abridged version of which will be serialised on this page very soon.

title: column-tourist-home-help-love-area
story: I WAS on holiday a couple of weeks ago and on one of the days I went to the local amenity site.There I found lots of people who, like myself, were pretending that clearing out the house was the next best thing to being in some far-off beauty spot.A few days later, I went out on an early morning cycle.As I came out from Musselburgh Lagoons towards the mouth of the Esk, I saw the magnicent sight of all the seabirds, the swans and the geese gathered at that point where river meets sea.It occurred to me then that my best holiday this year could be to live in my own place as though I were a tourist.In my own hometown, I can still be awed by unexpected beauty, delighted by the simple things that sometimes familiarity overlooks.I can take time to appreciate things that normally the hurry and the care of le make miss.Maybe being a tourist at home will help me love Musselburgh and East Lothian more.As a Christian, I know that my faith is not about denying the dficulty and pain that surrounds us.People of faith look to see the possibility of Godrsquos love reaching out to them, and from them to others, when le is hardest.Living with faith is about seeing the world in a way that expects to find hope.I know that recent months have been hard for people in so many ways.But I also have heard so many people say that they have seen more clearly what is important to them and the people they love because they have needed to slow down, to live more simply, to keep closer to home.Perhaps we have an invitation to reflect on the things that we have seen in a new way over the past months, things that we have appreciated and enjoyed.Perhaps we can all find hope in a promise we make to ourselves: we will enjoy the good things we have seen around us in new ways, and to hold onto the positive changes we have made in these hard times, even when our livesto lsquonormalrsquo.

title: new-long-term-parking-essential-say-north-berwick-traders
story: As part of East Lothianrsquos Council Spaces for People programme to help prevent the spread of coronavirus, bollards and planters have been placed along both sides of the road, widening the pavements and removing some parking spaces, allowing pedestrians to maintain social distancing.Nearby car parks, such as Kirk Ports and The Glebe, have been turned into  or -minute stays with nounder the scheme.David Turnbull, from Turnbullrsquos Home Hardware on High Street, said North Berwick needed more long-term parking for tourists and visitors who were likely to stay for longer than  minutes.He said: ldquoThere is now an excess of short-term and a shortage of long-term parking and, whether people were for or against the putting green [Elcho Green car park], it was a way of solving long-term parking.Council plans to construct a temporary car park at Elcho Green were put on hold after more than , people signed a petition against it.David said: ldquo[Without long-stay parking, fewer] visitors and residents are going to come [to the town centre]. There is a massive shortage of long-term spaces for these kinds of people.ldquoI can see why they want to put these measures [on the east end of High Street] in place but we need more long-term parking.David said he had visited two nearby car parks that had recently been made short term on two separate occasions and they were each one third empty.And he thought much of the opposition to the Elcho Green plan was due to misinformation about what it would consist of.David said that the new parking measures on High Street had not negatively affected his business and that there was enough short-term parking for his customers.Those at gt shop Time  Tide, however, say they have not been as busy since the measures were introduced.Staff member Lorraine, who has always lived in North Berwick, said: ldquoNorth Berwick is a seaside town and is not built for this kind of traffic.ldquoA lot of people live in flats and holiday homes nearby and they used those [long-term] car parks. These have now turned into short-term parking ndash where are these people to park now Lorraine said that restricting parking on the east end of High Street affected customers who wished to purchase heavy items such as furniture, as they would be unable to carry them to a car parked further away.She added: ldquoWersquove had to do something like a lsquosmash and grabrsquo, where we watch for the person coming and quickly put the item into their car.ldquoSome people think the area is pedestrianised and are walking on the road, whereas before the cars parked on the side of the road made people realise and they were walking on the pavement.Beverly Gilhooley, owner of pet shop Barker and Bone, said business was slightly quieter than usual but the restrictions made things ldquoa little safer, adding that she thought the short-term parking should be a permanent feature in summer.She said the restrictions suited the town during the summer, when tourism was high, but not during winter.She added that the restrictions had affected deliveries to her business, which were harder to carry out, and customers who wished to purchase heavy items.Beverly said: ldquoItrsquos a brilliant idea in summer but I hope itrsquos a more temporary thing every summer.We can keep this up for a couple of months but not for any longer.The North Berwick resident said her business could afford ldquoa little hit butthe parking restrictions continued through the winter her business would not survive.Judy Lockhart, chair of North Berwick Community Council, said the group wanted to know more about the councilrsquos future plans.She said on Monday: ldquoThe community council emailed East Lothian Council on July . . . and requested a meeting to discuss Elcho Green and have since followed our request up. To date, we have not been offered any times dates by the council.

title: tasty-chance-save-pounds-boosting-local-economy
story: Throughout August, customers heading to more than  businesses throughout the county can get a  per cent discount on food or non-alcoholic drinks to eat or drink ineach Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.Businesses from Whitecraig and Musselburgh in the west to Dunbar and Innerwick in the east are offering people the chance to make a saving on their bill through the Eat Out to Help Out scheme.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Councilrsquos spokesman for tourism and economic development, stressed the importance of such promotions.He said: ldquoAt a time when we are encouraging folk to stay safe, support local and love East Lothian, Eat Out to Help Out is a great way of supporting many of the fantastic eateries we have throughout the county and doing our bit to help with East Lothianrsquos economic recovery. Food and drink and hospitality are key sectors and we are keen to promote as much expenditure as possible within the local economy, while enabling our local communities to stay safe.Iain Gray MSP welcomed the Scotland Loves Local campaign, which ties in with other campaigns supporting the lsquoshop localrsquo message, such as Love Local Business, run by the Courier, and East Lothian Councilrsquos Stay Safe, Shop Local.The coronavirus has caused ldquosignicant challenges for town centres, high streets and businesses throughout the county.Mr Gray encouraged people to get out and support them where possible.He said: ldquoOur small businesses, whether a pub, cafe, butcher, newsagent or a grocery shop, are the leblood of local economies across East Lothian.ldquoWhether itrsquos an emergency pint of milk, catching up with old friends in the local pub or having a meal close to home, our town centres have always been there for us.ldquoNow is the time for us to support them to get back on their feet, by thinking local first. Thatrsquos a sentiment Irsquove always been pleased to support and help promote, because East Lothian boasts some of the best local shops and businesses anywhere in Scotland.DOZENS of restaurants, hotels, cafes and other visitor attractions in the county, such as garden centres, have signed up to the Eat Out to Help Out scheme.Businesses which have registered for the initiative can be found online via: www.tax.service.gov.uk eat-out-to-help-out find-a-restaurantHere we list the premises taking part in East Lothian. title: bus-route-extended-take-edinburgh-royal-infirmary
story: From Monday, Prentice Coachesrsquo  service will provide a direct link from the eastern side of Musselburgh to the hospital.There will be seven weekdayjourneys, setting off every hour from Seton Sands between am and pm, withjourneys from the hospital between am and pm.On a Saturday,  journeys will alternate with  journeys to provide a mostly hourly service from the hospital.This extension to the hospital service will be for a trial period to gauge customer demand.A spokesman for the Hadington-based bus firm said: ldquoService  has always been very popular with passengers but, due to being in a low fare zone, revenue was poor this added to the drop in overall passenger numbers due to Covid- has meant it has been very dficult to justy reinstating the route.ldquoWe hope the added option of travel to the Royal Infirmary will in time boost passenger numbers and then hopefully in due course we can expand the number of daily journeys.Meanwhile, a new  service is being launched on Monday. title: plans-revealed-transform-former-faside-lodge-site
story: East Lothian Council has revealed proposals for the site of the former Farsquoside Lodge, Tranent, which would see  cottage flats and bungalows built on the townrsquos Church Street.However, with Covid- restrictions making it dficult to host the normal public consultations which would see people go to a local centre or hall to view plans and give feedback, the council has launched it online, urging residents to get involved.The plans are described as being at the design stage and would see a mixture of mainstream and specialised housing with wheelchair access on the site with a mix of two and three-bedroom bungalows and one and two-bedroom cottage flats.Vehicle access to the new housing would be from neighbouring Elder Court and the design would follow the councilrsquos climate change strategy.Following the consultation, a planning application is expected to be lodged with the council and,approved, construction could be completed by .A council spokesperson said that the online consultation, which launched last Monday, would be open for comments and feedback until this Sunday.They said: ldquoThe councilrsquos development team would normally hold a local public consultation event to give the community an opportunity to discuss further, provide comments and raise any concerns. Due to the current situation, we are unable to hold any face-to-face events however, people can review the proposals and provide any feedback and concerns prior to the proposal being submitted to our planning department via the consultation hub.Farsquoside Lodge operated as a nursing home until October, when it was replaced by the new CrookstonCare Home in Tranent. The former building was demolished after the removal of asbestos.To get involved in the consultation, go to https:eastlothianconsultations policy-partnerships development-proposal-for-faside-lodge-tranent

title: pupils-face-school-bus-ban-masks-not-worn
story: The local authority has invested pound.million on increasing the number of buses for pupils when theyto school next week.However, it has introduced a face mask rule across all its home to school transport, including taxis, private school buses and public transport.Parents have been told children should also carry hand sanitiser which they are expected to use before boarding any school transport and put on their mask every day.The council, which provides transport for , children, said , of those pupils are provided with bus passes to use public buses on the routes with the rest using school buses contracted by the local authority and private hire taxis.MORE: What day does your high school childto school  Find out hereThe face mask rule will not apply to youngsters who are exempt under the exemption rules for public transport.New guidelines state that pupils on school buses should all be travelling to the same school so shared trips are no longer allowed so some routes shared by primary and secondary children are no longer available, eventhe children are from the same family.The council said  new buses have been commissioned across contractor and public service routes to allow pupils to continue to travel safely to school at a cost of pound.million.And it said guidance is being shared with families telling them to provide their children with hand sanitiser, which must be used prior to boarding the bus and face coverings which will be mandatory on all home to school transport.The council warned: ldquoFailing to adhere to these guidelines could lead to a pupil being refused entry to the bus.Seating plans will also be introduced on buses and families will receive details of timetables when they receive their bus passes.The council said the measures had been introduced in response to the current Covid- public health emergency and would be subject to review in line with any further Scottish Government guidelines.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet member for education and childrenrsquos services, said: ldquoI know this will be a relief for many parents who rely on our home to school transport services but who were also concerned about what this would look like in the current health emergency.ldquoOur officers have worked hard with transport partners to enable us to provide a service to families.ldquoWe are in the process of sending out bus passes and timetables and would ask that all families pay particular attention to their responsibilities for keeping their own children, drivers and other passengers safe. This will be essential to the operation of the service.

title: temporary-measures-introduced-tranent-aid-social-distancing
story: The measures, being introduced under East Lothian Councils Spaces for People scheme, will be monitored and changes may be madenecessary.They include a temporary introduction of a -minute parking limit in the Winton Place and Lindores Drive car parks to increase turnover and ensure visitors have spaces to park on High Street the -minute parking limit will also be introduced on Winton Place.Long-stay parking will be introduced at Foresters Park and the pedestrian crossing signals on High Street will be re-timed so the green man appears more frequently.Three parking spaces near congested footways on Bridge Street and High Street will be temporarily removed, says the council, to create more space for social distancing and queuing, something East Lothian Council says ldquowill be vital with schools ing and many pupils accessing the high street during lunch time.Most of the car parking spaces in Tranent town centre will continue to be available for use.Alongside these parking restrictions,  mile per hour speed limits will temporarily be introduced across the town alongside additional traffic calming measures.East Lothian Council says these will allow for a more flexible use of the town centre and allow it to respond to requests for the use of public space.It says the measures will also make it easier for people to cross the roadnecessary to maintain social distancing, support walking and cycling to school and enhance walking and cycling routes.The council also proposes to install electric-bike hire at Civic Square inlate autumn once the procurement process is complete.In addition, Ross High School will also be introducing staggered lunch breaks to reduce the number of pupils accessing the High Street at any one time.East Lothian Council says there was "engagement" with "key local stakeholders, including the community council, area partnership and local councillors" before all the measures were confirmed.

title: boots-open-booking-system-winter-flu-jab-service-early
story: The company say that so far, more than , people have registered with their winter flu jab service - which also aims to help relieve pressure on the NHS.According to new research comission by Boots UK,more people than ever considering a flu jab this winter, with almost a thirddoing so because they are more aware of the need to protect themselves against flu as a result of the Coronavirus pandemic.The research also round  per cent of people surveyed in the UK are more conscious about catching flu this winter than in previous years, and  per cent of people surveyed nationwide havent complete any essential paperwork and they will be asked not to speak to the pharmacist during the actual vaccination to minimise the risk of droplet spreading.If the consultation room is small, the pharmacist may ask to keep the door open during the appointment.Whatpharmacy services are available in Boots stores The following can be accessed in store or online at Boots:How can I book an appointment Boots say that customers will be able to book their appointments online and in store within the next few days with appointments available from mid-September.To book an appointment for the Winter Flu Jab Service at Boots,visit:https:www.boots online pharmacy-services winter-flu-jab-services.

title: scotland-schools-reopening-survey-reveals-teachers-really-feel
story: EIS conducted the survey, with interim results earlier this week showing less than one in five are confident that schools are currently safe.How many teachers completed the survey A total of , teachers completed the survey from its launch on Tuesday  August to the morning of Thursday  August.What do the teachers say While teachers want to see schools re-open, they remain unconvinced that sufficient measures have been put in place to ensure safety.The survey shows % of teachers support the decision to re-open schools.However only % express confidence that schools are currently safe ndash indicating that much more needs to be done to ensure safety.Just % of teachers are lsquovery confidentrsquo that there is sufficient evidence that Covid- is sufficiently under control to support a safeto school.And less than a quarter of teachers are lsquoconfident or very confidentrsquo that an established capacity to test, trace and isolate is in place to support a safe , with % expressing a lack of confidence.Interim Survey Results Highlight Teacher Concerns over Schools Reopening Next Week #EISNewshttps:t.co MKVWQAWeAThe survey also found that around % of teachers are confident that sufficient operational changes ndash such as effective social distancing and enhanced hygiene routines ndash will be in place to support a safeto school with % lacking confidence.And % of teachers feel either lsquosomewhat unsafersquo or lsquovery unsafersquo about ing to school next week.What does the teaching union say Commenting on the interim findings, EIS general secretary Larry Flanagan said, ldquoThe interim results of this survey highlight that Scotlandrsquos teachers continue to have serious questions over the re-opening of schools next week.ldquoThe fact that more than , teachers completed the survey in a little over a day illustrates the high degree of concern that remains over COVID- and schools.ldquoTeachers want to see schools re-opening, so that they can get back to working with pupils in the classroom environment ndash but they are very clear that this has to be done safely.ldquoThe initial indications from this major survey confirm that teachers believe that much more still needs to be done to ensure their safety, and the safety of pupils and others within the school, can be properly protected as schools re-open."The EIS will be sharing both the initial and final results of this survey with the Scottish Government and local authorities, and will be seeking urgent discussions on the mitigations that teachers still want to see ndash such as sufficient social distancing, testing for asymptomatic staff, and the use of face coverings where required to ensure safety.Scotlands schools will re-open full-time from  August, following scientic evidence and advice that it is safe to do so.Weve published guidance to support local authorities, teachers and parents to prepare for the new term.Read the guidance at https:t.co fcuOhEZj pic PKCJIZjWhen are schools back Scotlandrsquos schools are to reopen full time from August .What have the Scottish Government said A Scottish Government spokesman previously told PA: "Ensuring the highest quality education for our young people, in a safe environment, is our absolute priority, and we also want to make sure teaching staff feel supported."Our guidance clearly sets out the approach that must be taken, including a number of specic risk-mitigation measures that will need to be introduced in all schools in order that they provide a safe environment for staff and pupils."Inidual schools will carry out risk assessments on their estate, as they will know how to apply the guidance in a way that works best to ensure the safety of their setting."An enhanced surveillance programme for schools will allow us to closely monitor the impact of the pandemic on school age children and young people and staff and to make adjustments to the arrangements as necessary."

title: face-masks-scotland-mandatory-wearing-expanded-new-laws-visors
story: Currently, people in Scotland must wear some form of mask or covering on both public transport and in shops.Speaking at her daily briefing in Edinburgh, the Nicola Sturgeon says initial evidence suggests that compliance with those rules are very high.The wearing of face coverings in enclosed spacesis already in public guidance, but with Scotlands gradual move out of lockdown continuing, the First Minister announced further locations in which it would become mandatory.Where will I have to wear a mask Wearing a covering will now become mandatory in these situations:Full details will be available on the Scottish Government website.When will the changes come into force The changes will take place from Friday, August .What was said about visors The First Minister saidthat evidence suggests the wearing of face visors on their own is not enough.From next Friday, a face visor must be accompanied with another form of face covering.How will it be enforced The First Minister did not go into detail regarding this, however it is likely it will be enforced in a similar way to those on public transport and in shops.She previously said it would be "not fair or reasonable" to expect shop workers to enforce the rules - and instead it would be down to the police to do so.Fixed penalty notices - which start at pound - could be handed out by the police, but she says they will do so only at a last resort.Ms Sturgeon added: "All of us can help by doing this voluntarily because it can make a dference".Who is exempt Children under five will be exempt from this rule, Ms Sturgeon confirmed, along with those with certain medical conditions.Following in line with the public transport rules, then the following groups may also be exempt:But Ms Sturgeonsaid: ldquoFor everyone , face coverings will be mandatory."What  was announced The First Minister also announced that it will become mandatory by law for hospitality venues to take contact details for all customers.This is to help with the NHS Scotland Test and Protect schemeto stop the spread of the virus.

title: find-changes-planned-haddington-town-centre
story: East Lothian Council is considering a wide range of proposals across each of the countys major towns in a bid to ensure physical distancing in the streets.It is hoped the measures will ldquoenhance opportunities for walking and cycling, while supporting the reopening of businesses.Already, a town-wide  miles per hour speed limit has been introduced in Haddington, with the local authority now looking at potential changes in the town centre.Among the measures under consideration are:bull On the north side of High Street , where the road is wide, move parking spaces into the carriageway. This will widen the pavement area.bull On the south side of the High Street, widen the pavement at the western end.bull Re-configure parking on Market Street to increase space available for pedestrians .bull Alter pedestrian crossings to minimise wait time for pedestrians.bull Re-configure Station Road Hope Park junction to create more space for pedestrians.bull Introduce footpath build-outs on West Road to provide refuges for pedestrians to step into and let others pass, and also contribute to reducing vehicle speeds.bull Introduce footpath build-outs on Pencaitland Road to contribute to reducing vehicle speeds.A spokeswoman for the local authority told the Courier: ldquoThe vast majority of car parking spaces in Haddington town centre will continue to be available for use, with additional spaces currently available at John Muir House while many council staff continue to work remotely.Other measures to be explored before the end of the year include the installation of a public e-bikehire station for eight bicycles on Court Street.As the town gets busier and with pupils ing to school, other options ndash re-configuring Hardgate Victoria Terrace signals to create more space for pedestrians and closing Tynebank Road to through traffic to facilitate walking to school ndash will also be explored.

title: celeb-2020-five-scottish-castles-used-uk-series
story: The hugely popular show will be swapping the New South Wales jungle for a ruined castle somewhere in the UK ndash with speculation growing that it could be in Scotland.Ant and Dec will host the series as celebrities undertake gruelling trials and challenges to win food and treats in the lead-up to one of them being crowned king or queen of the castle, rather than the jungle.ITV recently confirmed that the  series of the show would go ahead amid the coronavirus crisis but did not offer details on where filming would take place.But where could the filming actually take place Herersquos fivecastles in Scotland that could be used:Caerlaverock CastleWhere: Dumfries and GallowayThis awe-inspiring castle is one of the finest in Scotland and would surely make for dramatic television.It has a moat ndash which could be perfect for water trials.And itrsquos twin towered gatehouse and imposing battlements make for a suitable backdrop for the special series.Doune CastleWhere: StirlingshireIf yoursquore looking for a castle suit for a TV production crew then look no further.Doune Castle featured heavily in Monty Python and the Holy Grail, Game of Thrones and Outlander.Itrsquos imposing tower and open grass courtyard could be utilised perfectly for Irsquom a Celeb.Blackness CastleWhere: Near FalkirkThis th century castle showcases spectacular views of the Firth of Forth ndash could that be perfect for Ant and Decrsquos speedboat arrival Like Doune Castle, Blackness also has a history of hosing film locations ndash with Mary Queen of Scots and Outlander.Aberdour CastleWhere: FeIf size is what TV production crew are after, then Aberdour could be in with a shout.The th century fortied estate hosts a large and imposing suite of buildings, with a large open garden perfect for our celebrity campsite.High walls could also prove a bonus ndash keeping unwanted eyes away from the site.Eilean Donan CastleWhere: Inverness-shireWe all know that when it comes to Irsquom a Celebrity, ITV like to go big.And where bigger than Scotlandrsquos most iconic castle, Eilean Donan.Itrsquos one of the most recognised castles in Scotland ndash which could prove a selling point when going from the beautul beaches of Australiarsquos Gold Coast and mysterious jungles to the less-spectacular sights of the UK.What have ITV said Kevin Lygo, ITVrsquos director of television, said: ldquoWe announced last week that we were doing all we could to make the series and Irsquom thrilled that we can bring the show to viewers, albeit not in the jungle.ldquoWe have a great team both on and off screen and I know they will produce a hugely entertaining series.Richard Cowles, director of entertainment at ITV Studios, said: ldquoWe pulled out all the stops to try and make the series happen in Australia.ldquoUnfortunately, due to the ongoing Covid- pandemic and despite us looking at many dferent contingencies, it became apparent that it just wasnrsquot possible for us to travel and make the show there.ldquoHowever, we are all really excited about a UK version of Irsquom A Celebrity. While it will certainly be dferent producing the show from the UK, the same tone and feel will remain.ldquoOur celebrities will probably have to swap shorts for thermals but they can still look forward to a basic diet of rice and beans and plenty of thrills and surprises along the way.

title: new-bbc-documentary-series-jamie-genevieve-great-indoors-air-week

title: list-glasgow-shops-administration-lockdown
story: Here we look at some of the businesses who will no longer be operating in the city and the ones under threat.Remnant KingsCity location: Howard StreetA total of  stafflost their jobs from the firmrsquos bases in Glasgow, Hamilton, and Edinburgh after the administrators were called in.The firm, which started in Glasgow in , said that although they were historically profitable, they have since suffered from declining turnover and trading dficulties in recent years caused by changing consumer habits.:Glasgow firm Remnant Kings goes into admistration resulting in job lossesOasis and Warehouse GroupCity locations past and present: Buchanan Galleries, Silverburn, Princes Square, and Glasgow Fort.The company behind Oasis and Warehouse went into administration in April when Deloitte was appointed as administrator.All stores haveclosed indefinitely whileonline sales have stopped.Reports say the fashion brands have been sold to restructuring business Hilco in a deal which includes stock but not the  stores or  concessions.Hash Ladha, chief executive of Oasis Warehouse, previouslysaid: ldquoThis is a situation that none of us could have predicted a month ago, and comes as shocking and dficult news for all of us.ldquoWe as a management team have done everything we can to try and save the iconic brands that we love.:Oasis and Warehouse who have shops in Glasgow fall into administrationCath KidstonCity location: Gordon StreetCath Kidston said they will not reopen their shops when lockdown ends.They called in the administrators in April with the closure of shops costing around  jobs.It is understood that the owner of the retro fashion brand has secured a deal to buy back the brand and its online operation. store leases.He will hope to save as many as  stores and , jobs.The firm announced the news in June.:Monsoon enters administration threatening over  job lossesQuizCity locations:Buchanan Street, St title: Marianne Taylor  The unanswerable question for every Scottish Tory leader
story: Few voters outside Moray know who Douglas Ross is. Recognition value within his own party may even be a moot point .Yet the -year-old north east native apparently believes he has what it takes to lead the Scottish Tories to victory in next Mayrsquos Holyrood election and achieve what his biggest supporter, Baroness Davidson of Lundin Links, failed to do: become First Minister.Despite no public profile to speak of and very little time to build one, Mr Rossrsquos approach over the last few days has certainly been bold. Ruthless, even, in way he and the party swept Jackson Carlaw aside.You get the feeling his campaign team hope for a Barack Obama-style recognition trajectory: at the beginning of  few knew who Obama was by the end of that year he was US President. If Mr Rossrsquos first approach to voters is anything to go by, however, the political figure we may be soon be comparing him to is Jo Swinson. Team Ross would be well-advised to learn lessons from the former Lib-Dem leaderrsquos disastrous  general election campaign, not least how poorly she communicated with voters in Scotland.Itrsquos early days, obviously, and Mr Ross hasnrsquot even been elected party leader yet, though this looks like a coronation rather than a competition. But the piece Mr Ross wrote for a newspaper yesterday, setting out his stall, was ill-conceived to say the least. Indeed, the sort of undecided voter his party desperately needs to pick up over the next few months may have found themselves themselves wincing, even chuckling, at some of the tone-deaf rhetoric.Herersquos an example. Near the beginning of the Sunday Times article Mr Ross states that ldquoa decade and more of nationalist government has left Scotland a ided country. Many readers, even those who donrsquot support the SNP, may immediately find themselves thinking about the how a decade of Tory government at Westminster has indeed left Scotland ided. Between the haves and the have nots. Between the working and the working poor. Between those who benefit from employment rights and those left at the mercy of the so-called gig-economy. Between those who rely on deliberately-underfunded public services and those who donrsquot have to.ldquoItrsquos the nature of nationalism to ide, Mr Ross goes on, seemingly without a hint of irony. The Little England narrative peddled by Boris Johnson and his cronies delivered Brexit at the ballot box, a isive and disastrous outcome that the vast majority of Scots remain economically, socially and ideologically opposed to.Letrsquos see how a no deal Brexit on  December - an outcome engineered and encouraged by a game-playing Prime Minister roundly despised and distrusted in Scotland - works out for Mr Rossrsquos Holyrood campaign. Such a result would undoubtedly heap even more misery upon Scottish businesses already on the brink after what will, by the end of the year, be -months of Covid--related downturn.Mr Ross is apparently a keen supporter of Boris JohnsonMaybe he truly believes he can influence Mr Johnson on Brexit policy where Ruth Davidson, David Mundell and Jackson Carlaw failed.But there lies the fundamental, inescapable rub for Scottish Tories. It doesnrsquot matter who leads them. They are shackled to a UK party that appears to revel in acting against the best interests of Scotland.Those most committed to the Union will still cast their votes for the party next May. They have nowhere  to go.But polls over the last few months have detected a sht. The size of this steadfastly pro-Union group looks like it is decreasing, largely due to Brexit. Younger voters remain overwhelmingly in support of independence.In a bid to counter this, Mr Ross refers throughout the aforementioned article to patriotism, a term associated with the sort of brash Brexiteers most in Scotland canrsquot stand, and is surely no less problematic than ldquonationalism.The architects of his campaign - among them Michael Gove - have little choice but to focus on ldquosaving the Union. But how do you even begin to do this when your own party works against you at every turn  That remains the enduring, unanswerable question for whoever leads the Scottish Tories.

title: herald-sunday-letters-readers-talking-week
story: Were the bill to become law, much would hinge on the definition of what was ldquolikely to ensue after an inidual had expressed an opinion to which A. N. Other had taken exception. As a criminal offence, proving that such a likelihood lay ldquobeyond reasonable doubt would surely be the test, rather than that it was so ldquoon the balance of probabilities. An estimate that there was a  per cent chance of something happening would be insufficient grounds for a convictionhellipor would it  The best of luck in deciding that point, Mrsquolud.In George Orwellrsquos imaginary world, ldquoThoughtcrime was a criminal offence. This bill threatens to take us a step closer to such a terrying reality.Bob Scott, Drymen.IrsquoM no lawyer, but with the ldquothe vagueness of the bill being one of the many concerns the Law Society of Scotland has highlighted, I may be forgiven for concluding that the wording of the SNPrsquos Hate Crime Bill, could lead to some entertaining scenarios.Imagine the situation where one of the many proposed "protected groups"does or says something that another of the "protected groups"deems to be offensive or "stirring up hatred" towards group B. No corroboration would be needed for group B to justy the complaint and resultant charges against group A, but immediately on doing so, it would be acting in a way that could "stir up hatred" against group A. Group A would then have a valid complaint which could presumably result in the group B being charged. There would also be documentary evidencethat group B had acted against group A.Comedy potential aside, the implications of the bill on the future of free speech in Scotland are scary and anyone who is not familiar with the proposals should be finding out more. If you come to the same conclusions as many, including The Law Society of Scotland, the Scottish Police Federation and the Catholic Church, then voice your concerns to your elected representative.Mark Openshaw, Aberdeen.I AM ALIVE AT  BECAUSE OF THE A-BOMBSI READ with great interest the article by David Pratt . I am a -year-old veteran and former Japanese POW.A survivor of "the Death Railway" and working on defence tunnels in Singapore, later this month I shall pay a part in the Royal British Legions Scottish VJ Remembrance. Seventy-five years ago I walked out of Changi prison weighing only six stone, and since that time I have remembered comrades who never came home, but I also know that I am alive today because those terrible weapons of war were used.I have recalled those events every day since, they never leave me, and I do have a sense of guilt that I still enjoy le whilst people in Japan remember with sorrow family members they have lost.Eleven years ago I went back to the River Kwai to pay respects to those pals who are buried in Kanchanaburi Cemetery andit was very pleasing to find Japanese tourists there doing likewise. I also say "never again".Jack Ransom , Largs.DAVID Pratts article discussing the Cold War legacy of the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki did not mention the part played by the United Kingdom Government in the further development of these nuclear weapons.The UKrsquos development of nuclear weapons involved testing these weapons in Australia and on the small North Pacic island of Kiritimafrom  to . This has resulted in long-term suffering to the native Australian population and to the native inhabitants of Kiritima. There were also around , British servicemen involved in these tests. Many of these servicemen died at an early age, from a multitude of rare and unexplained illnesses, a large number of their wives had miscarriages, often multiple, and many of their descendants are now suffering from ious unexplained illnesses.For years successive governments have denied that these deaths and illnesses were in anyway linked to the servicemenrsquos presence at these tests. At present the British Nuclear Veterans Association is campaigning for the Government to award a medal to the men involved in these tests. We wait, but time is running out, as we the veterans grow older.Colin Moir, Peterhead.UNIVERSITIESrsquo WRONG ATTITUDEYOUR investigation into the university funding situationseems to have turned up a number of issues that we are forced to confrontwe are to arrive at a satisfactory resolution to them.The Glasgow University principal was concerned about the loss of soft power from decreased Chinese students as a reason to justy dependence on the Chinese state. That adequately demonstrates firmer power in action within that relationship.A cost to Scottish students that was not mentioned was the increased housing costs. Large numbers of well-funded international students have driven up the price for local accommodation and has pushed many Scottish students to live further away from their place of study, particularly for the less well-off. An extra hour of daily commuting is a large cost over four or more years.We were told that our universities let out a collective sigh of relief that they will not have to refocus on Stemsubjects, health workers or teachers. This is the wrong attitude and is looking at education costs without consideration of value. Give the universities the money but only for areas of greatest consequence. Train more doctors, dentists, scientists and engineers here in Scotland.Tom Walker, Loanhead.LETrsquoS KEEP FIGHTING TOGETHERI HAVE noticed that during this coronavirus pandemic ndash currently ongoing contrary to popular belief ndash that the usual snipers from both sides of the independence debate continue to have a sneaky shot when the opportunity arises. However, I would like to take the opportunity to thank all political leaders and players of the Scottish Parliament for largely sticking together and following a clear strategy to eliminate Covid- from Scotland.Nicola Sturgeon is the First Minister of Scotland and with the support of the Scottish Parliament and her scientic advisors has worked tirelessly to ensure that everyone in Scotland is clear on what is expected of us to help achieve zero Covid- in Scotland. Thanks should also go to Jason Leitch for the clarity of his guidance both to the Scottish people in general and directly to the wider UK audience when answering specic questions - you are a credit to Scotland.Every political leader in Scotland should step forward and take a bow on current performance in tackling Covid- and take a vow to continue working together until normal service is resumed. The time will come when you can all resume your normal ndash but insignicant ndash bickering, but in the meantime, thanks for all your efforts in showing a united front and keeping Scotland safe.In the words of my -year-old mum, ldquoI donrsquot really bother much about politics, but I feel safe in Scotland, wersquore in good hands with Nicola.Letrsquos keep fighting this current pandemic together and make it our priority to lead by example by keeping Scotland safe.Tom Cassells, Ayr.SPORTSCENE SPOILEDTHERE was considerable excitement and anticipation at the prospect of theof Saturday night Sportscene after a long absence of  years.That was because the Scottish football public had inferred the programme was going to be the hugely successful line-up of Jonathan Sutherland, Steven Thomson and Michael Stewart. They are a marriage made in heaven because they are experienced, intelligent, articulate, get on well together and their sense of fun and banter reflects that. Few BBC Scotland programmes get a bigger audience. It was the jewel in their crown.What on earth have they done  Gone is the highly articulate Michael Stewart, who has played at the highest level and speaks with authority. Were they leaned on Some critics have suggested this is the familiar London-based tick-box political correctness, given Sportscene is inflicting Shelley Kerr, Leanne Crichton and Julie Fleeting on us. For some time now they have failed on the likes of Saturday Sportscene Results where the likes of David Currie have rescued them repeatedly. On Championship Sportscene they are rescued by Steven Thomson. They detract from both programmes. Both presenters have had to resort to questions where the reply was framed by the question.Yes they are intelligent, articulate and friendly but they are experts on the womens game. They do not have the background knowledge of the mens game outwith the big five clubs, so the expertise and spontaneity are jettisoned to the detriment of the programme.They do have some excellent guests like Marvin Bartley and James McFadden, who merge their knowledge of the game with a great ability to poke fun at themselves, but neither is a pundit.This has been a great disappointment. I am not alone in these views. The BBC should have a look at fans forums.John V Lloyd, Inverkeithing.P FOR YOUR THOUGHTSA FRIEND recently reached her th birthday and received a letter from Westminsters Department of Work and Pensions, informing her that shed be receiving an increase in her state pension. When she checked, it turned out to be an increase of p a week. She quickly checked her pension credit ndashonly to find that it had been reduced by p a week. How do readers think she could best spend her p bounty for cheating death in one of the worlds richest countries Ian Waugh, Dumfries.

title: opinion-mark-smith-us-really-ever-change
story: But I may have a point, in some ways. There are other nine-year-olds in that old school picture of mine and I remember them well. One of them, Alex, is standing next to me, scowling out from beneath his fringe. Much later, when he was grown up, Alex became a heroin addict and was hit by a car while he was high and killed instantly, aged . I only found out years later, when someone mentioned it to me, casually. Did I know Alex was dead Therersquos change for you: a bit of my childhood broken off. Alex and I had a dficult relationship. He could be bit of a bully to be honest, but he was only nine and so was I, and one day, when wersquod got into a fight in the playground, I suddenly got the better of him for once and pinned him down and said, ldquoWhat you going to do now, eh  and that was that the fighting stopped and we became friends. Sort of.I find another picture. . The year before the school photo was taken. Oldmeldrum Highland Games in Aberdeenshire, warm, sunny, happy, and there in the middle of the photo, driving towards us in an open-top Rolls Royce ndash in Aberdeenshire! in the s! ndash is the actress Diana Dors ndash in Aberdeenshire! in the s! I didnrsquot know it then of course, but the reason Diana Dors was at Oldmeldrum Highland Games was because her career had hit the skids and she was opening country fetes for cash. I thought it was exciting. She probably felt dead inside. But therersquos change for you: she was a film star once.I put the pictures in a pile and sort through some books that need organising and therersquos a copy of Michael Palinrsquos diaries from the s and s, my childhood. I flick through them and change seems to back off again. Therersquos an entry from November  thatrsquos like a Monty Python sketch: Michael is in a book shop in Edinburgh and an irate lady mistakes him for the shopkeeper and tells him she feels cheated because the book about angling she bought for her nephew has two pages stuck together. Maybe the woman was Terry Jones in a dress doing the Spam voice. These pages are stuck together! Itrsquos a scam, scam, scam!But itrsquos the other entries in Palinrsquos diaries ndash interesting, anxious little snippets from the past ndash that really hang around in my brain. He mentions Scottish politics and says that he hopes that, one day, Scotland will be independent. December st : ldquoI would like to see Wales and Scotland as independent nations and I think itrsquos going to happen as people gets less and less satisfaction from being part of a big international wodge.He also rages against the Tories. April st, : ldquoSensitivity, tolerance, understanding and conciliation is a spirit utterly alien to the Thatcher-inspired politics of the s, he writes. And where in the diaries, despite all his success in comedy and films, he worries that he might not be good enough.None of that has changed, has it  Wersquore still angry. We still worry. At one point, Palin notices how much his face has aged ndash and thatrsquos a change that certainly cannot be resisted ndash but the Tories are still the Tories and worries are still worries and, reading the diaries, I feel the connection from now to then and the sense of what hasnrsquot altered at all. There they were: all those people in , including Michael Palin, complaining about the state of things and wanting reform, and herersquos , with lots of people complaining about the state of things and wanting reform. Itrsquos the thing that doesnrsquot change, ever: the desire for change.And now that Irsquom back in the s and s, rummaging about in the years that have gone, I remember something  about that picture of me at school in Torry, Aberdeen, in . t was the year I created a school magazine. I appointed myself editorand chief writerand commissioned myself to write a review of The Krankies at the Capitol theatre and a story about a pair of magic skis. My writing was cobbled together and amateurish and childish andsome people say it still is. You see: nothing changes.So, I tidy the pictures away, and put Palinrsquos diaries up on the shelf, but the photograph from  ndash the one of me next to my teacher and Alex, the boy who died ndash is staying out on my desk. Itrsquos propped up against the wall where I can see it and it reminds me and warns me. It reminds me of the stuff that changes and the stuff that doesnrsquot. And the warning is clear:I want change, time is running out.

title: notes-africa-sour-milk-groundnut-butter-lovely-honestly
story: The diet of our neighbours, the Dinka tribe of South Sudan, has always been based on fresh or sour milk, together with blood drawn off from the jugular veins of their cattlersquos necks. This provided sufficient protein and calories when they were nomadic pastoralists but due to the endless and ongoing civil wars, hundreds of thousands of Dinka have now been herded into refugee camps in East Africa, sans milk, sans blood. Whether the World Food Programmesrsquos maize, rice and flour will affect their towering heights, protuberant teeth or aggressive egos remains to be seen.The next is groundnut butter, made by roasting the nuts in a wok-like container over the open fire after adding a handful of river sand, then swirling it round till the red skins peel off. The sandless, huskless nuts are then crushed on a grinding stone ndash back-breaking work ndash and stored in a clay pot which is sealed. The end result resembles not at all its commercial relation in First world supermarkets, being a dense, deep brown, highly aromatic sludge two or three teaspoonfuls added to sweet potatoes will sate the appetite till the next morning. While peanut allergy in its several forms is frequent in Britain and a cause of misery to many, both adults and children, I have yet to see a case in East Africa, probably because no additives or preservatives are added to the peanuts.Simsim or sesame seed butter is even richer than the groundnut version, with a tart taste and no sweetness but rather a hint of the savoury. The richness is such that it often has to be mixed with its peanut cousin to avoid your liver and gallbladder seizing up in shocked spasm.My third addiction is trimming all finger nails to the quick. This is not a fetish or an obsession, because it serves a useful , being a necessity professionally. However after decades of scrubbing up for surgery, major or minor, or for delivering babies, you become uneasy, even irritable,the nails en beyond a certain limit. Until they are attended to, there is a reluctance to expose them in public. A Nigerian colleague who enjoys one-upmanship often produces a smart nailfile when we talk and smiles knowingly when I at once clasp both hands behind my back.Finally there is kisra, a very thin pancake, made of sorghum, maize or wheat flour mixed with water. It is cooked on a plate-sized skillet over a charcoal fire, each pancake being peeled off once ready and added to the growing pile.The skillet is lightly wiped with groundnut or sesame oil before the next offering is poured onto the hot surface. They are eaten freshly cooked, rolled up with a iety of spicy fillings or used as dippers for mouthfuls of meat, fish or vegetable stews.Chapatis are much thicker than their kisra brothers, with oil added to the mix. A popular street food, they have saved the lives of many batchelors, especially the lsquoRollexrsquowhere a beaten egg is poured over the almost-cooked upper surface at the crucial moment. As a connoisseur educated me while eating one in Gulursquos main market, their makers have a vocation, the resulting chapati having a tensile strength unknown to lesser ieties of pancake and certainly not as effete as a crepe.Dr David Vost studied medicine at Glasgow University and is currently working at a hospital in Swaziland. He and his family live on a small farm in Northern Uganda near the Albert Nile. davidvostsz@gmail

title: big-read-dog-saved-life-pets-got-us-lockdown---animals-pay-price
story: Clyde is a two-year-old chocolate Labrador and when I speak to Ali over the phone, hersquos fast asleep at her feet. Occasionally, he likes to get up and demand a cuddle, but mostly hersquos just enjoying the nap and the fact that therersquos nothing much to do today.Ali says she could not have survived lockdown without Clyde. The young dog got her through the worst period of her le, she says, and then when things were looking a bit better, lockdown hit and he got her through that too. Being on your own for weeks on end is disconcerting, says Ali, but it helped to have the dog at her feet. You canrsquot be truly alonetherersquos a dog around.Ali isnrsquot the only one who feels that way. The Battersea Cat and Dog Home has been doing some research recently into how our relationship with pets has been affected by the lockdown conditions and the conclusion is that, for many of us, the negative effects have been eased by having a dog or cat about the place. Many pet-owners report that their anxiety about the situation has been eased or reduced by their pet.This is certainly true for Ali Ramsay. The -year-old from Glasgow used to be a Flight Lieutenant in the RAF and was totally immersed in the military le. ldquoIt was my work le, my social le, my fitness le ndash I played volleyball for the RAF, she says. ldquoIt was everything.Then she was diagnosed with Fibromyalgia, a long-term condition that causes chronic pain, and she was medically discharged from the service. It was the beginning of a long dark period in her le.ldquoI didnrsquot want to leave the RAF, she says. ldquoI had  more years of career ahead of me and I wanted that career, but because of my condition, I was medically discharged. It wasnrsquot a choice. I had no career, no purpose. And then I had tribunals just to get my disability pension so I had financial worries. I would have lost my houseit wasnrsquot for my family and forces charities helping me out. So I was in a bit of a dire state.It got so bad that at one point, she says, she considered suicide ndash she was depressed because of the pain and had lost all the enjoyment in her le. But thatrsquos when she contacted the Scottish charity Bravehound which matches dogs with veterans to improve the quality of their lives. Suddenly, there was some purpose back in Alirsquos le and it was brought about by a chocolate Labrador called Clyde.ldquoI needed the dog sooner rather than later, says Ali, ldquoor I wouldrsquove found myself not being here. I was going through hard times and I needed the dog to live. The dference between ending my le and living was having a dog. It gave me something to live for, and a project, and a focus. He was the dference between having somebody  to care for when I didnrsquot care about myself.The positive effects of Clyde have also been amplied by the lockdown. Before the restrictions were imposed, Ali was attending regular training sessions with Clyde and meetings with other veterans and then, suddenly, it all stopped. No more meetings. No more socialising, although the training sessions have continued on Zoom.ldquoI was in my home  , says Ali, ldquoand the only thing to get me out was walking Clyde. And although everyone was socially distanced, even saying hello to another dog walker, I had some human connection. Also, having Clyde around the house got me through it. I would talk to him ndash although hersquos a dog, hersquos another being and I was able to talk to him and interact with him all the time. Hersquos either lying beside me at my feet or on the bed.
